Montenegro has historically experienced seasonal strain on its electricity grid, and access to deeper, more liquid cross-border markets reduces the risk of supply disruptions during peak tourist months. For a sector where a single prolonged blackout at a major coastal resort can generate international negative press and booking cancellations, this reliability improvement is meaningful.

The decision also strengthens Montenegro's positioning as an EU-aligned destination. Tour operators, international hotel chains, and cruise lines increasingly evaluate regulatory and infrastructure stability when making investment and routing decisions. Completing the transposition ahead of formal EU membership, as only the third Energy Community contracting party to do so, sends a credible signal of institutional capacity and reform momentum. This is particularly relevant given Montenegro's competition with Croatia (already an EU member with full market integration) and Albania (which lags behind on such reforms). Porto Montenegro in Tivat, luxury developments in Lustica Bay, and planned resort investments along the coast all benefit from this improved investment climate.

Furthermore, the clearer framework for renewable energy investment that accompanies market integration aligns well with the growing eco-tourism segment. Montenegro's national parks, Skadar Lake, and the northern mountain regions are marketed on the strength of pristine natural environments. A credible energy transition pathway supports Montenegro's green brand, which is increasingly important for EU-origin tourists who represent the core market.

However, the most significant concern from a tourism perspective is the price risk. The OECD has documented that Montenegro's household retail electricity prices are approximately 89% below market-consistent reference levels, maintained artificially low by the state-owned utility EPCG. As Montenegro integrates into the EU electricity market, prices will face upward pressure toward convergence. Even a partial convergence could substantially increase operating costs for the hospitality sector. Hotels, particularly smaller family-run establishments along the coast and in the north, operate on thin margins and are poorly equipped to absorb significant energy cost increases. This could lead to higher room rates, reducing Montenegro's price competitiveness, or to reduced service quality and deferred maintenance as operators cut costs elsewhere.

The seasonal labour dynamics compound this concern. Montenegro already requires approximately 20,000 foreign seasonal workers annually, and accommodation and food service businesses face tight margins. If energy costs rise without compensating productivity gains or targeted support, some smaller operators may exit the market entirely, potentially reducing the diversity of accommodation offerings that tourists value.

Crucially, the decision as announced contains no tourism-specific provisions or transition support for the hospitality sector. While the World Bank has previously analysed the poverty and environmental impacts of electricity price reform in Montenegro, there is no indication that the government has developed sector-specific mitigation strategies for tourism businesses that would face disproportionate impact due to their energy-intensive and seasonal nature.
key_concerns: Electricity price convergence with EU market levels could significantly increase operating costs for hotels, restaurants, and tourism accommodation, with OECD data showing current prices are 89% below market-consistent reference levels

Small and medium-sized tourism operators, particularly family-run coastal hotels and guesthouses, have thin margins and limited capacity to absorb energy cost increases without raising prices or cutting quality
No tourism-specific transition support or energy cost mitigation measures have been announced alongside the transposition package
Seasonal demand spikes for electricity during peak tourist months (May-October) could expose the tourism sector to volatile spot market pricing once full market coupling is achieved

Rising energy costs could erode Montenegro's price competitiveness against regional rivals, particularly Albania which maintains lower cost structures, and could push budget-conscious tourists to alternative destinations

The short-term rental sector (Airbnb, Booking.com properties) is largely unregulated in energy efficiency terms and could face particular cost pressure, potentially reducing supply or pushing costs to visitors
recommendations: Coordinate with the Ministry of Energy to develop a tourism-sector energy transition roadmap that includes phased price adjustment timelines and targeted support for hospitality businesses

Establish an energy efficiency retrofit incentive programme specifically for tourism accommodation, including grants or low-interest loans for solar panel installation, heat pumps, building insulation, and smart energy management systems in hotels

Negotiate with EPCG and the energy regulator for a seasonal tariff structure that recognizes the unique demand patterns of tourism businesses, potentially with off-peak incentives for pre-cooling and load shifting
Require energy performance certificates for all licensed tourism accommodation as part of a broader quality and sustainability rating system aligned with EU tourism standards

Develop a Montenegro Green Tourism label that rewards energy-efficient accommodation providers, creating a market incentive for voluntary energy transition and appealing to environmentally conscious EU tourists
Commission an impact assessment specifically modelling the effects of various electricity price convergence scenarios on tourism sector competitiveness, employment, and accommodation supply

Ensure that renewable energy investment incentives created by the new legal framework are accessible to tourism businesses, particularly for rooftop solar installations on coastal hotels and eco-lodges near national parks

counter_proposal.title: Tourism Energy Transition Support Package
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Tourism would advocate for a parallel Tourism Energy Transition Support Package to accompany the electricity market integration. Rather than allowing the tourism sector to absorb energy price convergence passively, this package would proactively support hospitality businesses in reducing energy intensity before prices rise, turning what could be a competitive threat into a sustainability advantage. The package would combine mandatory energy audits for licensed accommodation, a dedicated retrofit fund co-financed by EU IPA III and EBRD resources, a phased timeline linking tourism sector price exposure to measurable energy efficiency improvements, and a Montenegro Green Tourism certification scheme.
key_changes: Introduce mandatory energy audits for all licensed tourism accommodation within 18 months, with results feeding into a national tourism energy baseline

Establish a Tourism Energy Efficiency Fund of at least 10 million euros, co-financed through EU IPA III pre-accession funds and EBRD green economy financing, to provide grants covering 40-60% of retrofit costs for small and medium hospitality operators
Negotiate a transitional electricity tariff for registered tourism businesses that phases in market-rate pricing over 3-5 years, contingent on participation in energy efficiency programmes
Launch a Montenegro Green Tourism certification scheme with tiered energy performance requirements, integrated into the national tourism quality rating system and promoted in destination marketing
Amend short-term rental licensing requirements to include minimum energy efficiency standards, aligning the informal accommodation sector with the broader transition
expected_benefits: Reduced energy costs per guest-night by 25-40% for participating accommodation providers, partially offsetting market price convergence
Enhanced destination competitiveness through sustainability credentials that appeal to the growing segment of environmentally conscious European tourists
Attraction of additional EU pre-accession and green financing by demonstrating a credible sector-specific transition plan
Protection of seasonal employment by maintaining the economic viability of small tourism operators who collectively account for the majority of seasonal jobs
Alignment with EU tourism sustainability frameworks, strengthening Montenegro's Chapter 20 (Enterprise and Industrial Policy) negotiating position
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High feasibility. The EBRD invested a record 215 million euros in Montenegro in 2025, with significant green economy focus. EU IPA III pre-accession funds are available for energy transition support. The Energy Community framework explicitly supports complementary sectoral measures. Croatia has already implemented similar hotel energy efficiency programmes under EU cohesion funds, providing a tested regional model. The main implementation risk is administrative capacity within the Ministry of Tourism and coordination with the energy regulator, which could be mitigated through a dedicated project implementation unit.
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Ministarstvo turizma zalagalo bi se za paralelni Paket podrške energetskoj tranziciji turizma koji bi pratio integraciju tržišta električne energije. Umjesto da se turističkom sektoru pasivno prepusti apsorpcija konvergencije cijena energije, ovaj paket bi proaktivno podržao ugostiteljska preduzeća u smanjenju energetskog intenziteta prije nego što cijene porastu, pretvarajući ono što bi moglo biti konkurentska prijetnja u prednost u oblasti održivosti. Paket bi obuhvatao obavezne energetske audite za licencirani smještaj, namjenski fond za retrofiting koji bi sufinansirali EU IPA III i EBRD, fazni vremenski okvir koji bi povezao izloženost turističkog sektora cijenama sa mjerljivim poboljšanjima energetske efikasnosti, te shemu sertifikacije Zeleni turizam Crne Gore.
key_changes_mne: Uvođenje obaveznih energetskih audita za sav licencirani turistički smještaj u roku od 18 mjeseci, pri čemu bi rezultati činili osnovu nacionalne energetske referentne vrijednosti u turizmu

Osnivanje Fonda za energetsku efikasnost u turizmu od najmanje 10 miliona eura, sufinansiranog kroz EU IPA III pretpristupne fondove i EBRD finansiranje zelene ekonomije, radi dodjele grantova koji pokrivaju 40–60% troškova retrofitinga za male i srednje ugostiteljske operatere

Pregovaranje o prelaznoj tarifi za električnu energiju za registrovana turistička preduzeća, koja bi postepeno uvodila tržišne cijene tokom 3–5 godina, uslovljeno učešćem u programima energetske efikasnosti

Pokretanje sheme sertifikacije Zeleni turizam Crne Gore sa stupnjevitim zahtjevima u pogledu energetskih performansi, integrisane u nacionalni sistem ocjenjivanja kvaliteta turizma i promovisane u destinacijskom marketingu
Izmjena uslova licenciranja kratkoročnog iznajmljivanja kako bi se uveli minimalni standardi energetske efikasnosti, usklađujući neformalni smještajni sektor sa širom tranzicijom
expected_benefits_mne: Smanjenje troškova energije po gost-noćenju za 25–40% za smještajne objekte koji učestvuju u programu, čime se djelimično ublažava konvergencija tržišnih cijena
Unapređenje konkurentnosti destinacije kroz akreditive održivosti koji privlače rastuće segment ekološki svjesnih evropskih turista
Privlačenje dodatnih EU pretpristupnih i zelenih finansiranja demonstriranjem vjerodostojnog plana tranzicije specifičnog za sektor
Zaštita sezonskog zapošljavanja kroz očuvanje ekonomske održivosti malih turističkih operatera koji zajedno čine većinu sezonskih radnih mjesta
Usklađenost sa okvirima EU za održivost turizma, čime se jača pregovaračka pozicija Crne Gore u okviru Poglavlja 20 (Preduzetništvo i industrijska politika)
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka izvodljivost. EBRD je 2025. godine investirala rekordnih 215 miliona eura u Crnu Goru, sa značajnim fokusom na zelenu ekonomiju. EU IPA III pretpristupna sredstva dostupna su za podršku energetskoj tranziciji. Okvir Energetske zajednice eksplicitno podržava komplementarne sektorske mjere. Hrvatska je već implementirala slične programe energetske efikasnosti hotela u okviru EU kohezionih fondova, pružajući isprobani regionalni model. Glavni rizik pri implementaciji je administrativni kapacitet Ministarstva turizma i koordinacija s energetskim regulatorom, što bi se moglo ublažiti osnivanjem namjenske jedinice za implementaciju projekta.

assessments.summary_mne: Završetak transpozicije EU paketa za integraciju tržišta električne energije u Crnoj Gori predstavlja uglavnom pozitivan razvoj za turistički sektor. On jača sigurnost snabdijevanja energijom (što je ključno tokom vršne sezone od maja do oktobra, kada obalni hoteli i klimatizacija uzrokuju skokove potražnje), šalje pozitivne investicione signale investitorima u ugostiteljstvo i učvršćuje imidž Crne Gore kao vjerodostojne, modernizujuće destinacije usklađene s EU. Međutim, ova odluka nosi značajan rizik u srednjoročnom periodu: kako cijene električne energije budu konvergirale ka nivoima EU tržišta (prema analizi OECD-a, trenutne crnogorske cijene su otprilike 89% ispod tržišno usklađenih referentnih cijena), operativni troškovi hotela, restorana i turističke infrastrukture mogli bi znatno porasti, dovodeći u pitanje cjenovnu konkurentnost na kojoj počiva vrijednosna ponuda Crne Gore u odnosu na Hrvatsku, Albaniju i Grčku.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Paket integracije tržišta električne energije u cjelini je pozitivan za turizam zahvaljujući poboljšanoj energetskoj sigurnosti i povećanom povjerenju investitora, međutim nosi ozbiljan srednjoročni rizik od rasta cijena električne energije koji bi mogao ugroziti cjenovnu konkurentnost crnogorskog ugostiteljskog sektora. Ministarstvo turizma preporučuje da se mjere podrške energetskoj tranziciji specifične za turizam – uključujući podsticaje za obnovljive izvore energije za hotele i programe energetske obnove objekata – razvijaju paralelno s liberalizacijom tržišta.
key_concerns_mne: Konvergencija cijena električne energije s nivoima EU tržišta mogla bi značajno povećati operativne troškove hotela, restorana i turističkog smještaja – podaci OECD-a pokazuju da su trenutne cijene 89% ispod tržišno usklađenih referentnih nivoa

Mali i srednji turistički operateri, posebno porodični obalni hoteli i pansioni, posluju s tankim maržama i ograničenim kapacitetom da apsorbuju povećanje troškova energije bez podizanja cijena ili smanjenja kvaliteta
Uz paket transpozicije nisu najavljene nikakve mjere podrške specifične za turizam niti mjere za ublažavanje troškova energije

Sezonski skokovi potražnje za električnom energijom tokom vršnih turističkih mjeseci (maj–oktobar) mogli bi izložiti turistički sektor volatilnom određivanju cijena na spot tržištu nakon postizanja punog tržišnog spajanja

Rast troškova energije mogao bi narušiti cjenovnu konkurentnost Crne Gore u odnosu na regionalne rivale, posebno Albaniju koja zadržava niže troškovne strukture, i mogao bi usmjeriti turiste s ograničenim budžetom prema alternativnim destinacijama

Sektor kratkoročnog iznajmljivanja (nekretnine na platformama Airbnb i Booking.com) uglavnom nije regulisan u smislu energetske efikasnosti i mogao bi biti izložen posebnom troškovnom pritisku, što bi potencijalno smanjilo ponudu ili prebacilo troškove na posjetioce
recommendations_mne: Koordinirati s Ministarstvom energetike radi izrade mape puta energetske tranzicije za turistički sektor, koja obuhvata fazne rokove prilagođavanja cijena i ciljanu podršku ugostiteljskim preduzećima

Uspostaviti program podsticaja za energetsku obnovu objekata namijenjen isključivo turističkom smještaju, uključujući grantove ili kredite s niskom kamatom za ugradnju solarnih panela, toplotnih pumpi, termoizolacije zgrada i sistema za pametno upravljanje energijom u hotelima

Pregovarati s EPCG-om i energetskim regulatorom o sezonskoj tarifnoj strukturi koja prepoznaje specifične obrasce potražnje turističkih preduzeća, uz potencijalne podsticaje za predsezono hlađenje i pomjeranje opterećenja van vršnih sati
Uvesti energetske certifikate o performansama kao obavezu za sav licencovan turistički smještaj, u okviru šireg sistema ocjenjivanja kvaliteta i održivosti usklađenog s EU standardima za turizam

Razviti crnogorsku oznaku Zelenog turizma koja nagrađuje pružaoce energetski efikasnog smještaja, stvarajući tržišni podsticaj za dobrovoljnu energetsku tranziciju i privlačeći ekološki osvješćene turiste iz EU

Naručiti procjenu uticaja kojom bi se posebno modelirale posljedice različitih scenarija konvergencije cijena električne energije na konkurentnost turističkog sektora, zaposlenost i ponudu smještajnih kapaciteta

Osigurati da podsticaji za ulaganje u obnovljive izvore energije, nastali novim pravnim okvirom, budu dostupni turističkim preduzećima, posebno za ugradnju solarnih panela na krovovima obalnih hotela i eko-smještaja u blizini nacionalnih parkova

assessments.summary: The completion of the EU electricity market integration package transposition is a welcome step in Montenegro's broader EU harmonization process, demonstrating the government's capacity to align domestic legislation with the EU acquis communautaire. From a justice perspective, the legislative framework -- comprising the Energy Law and the Cross-border Electricity and Natural Gas Exchange Law adopted by Parliament, supplemented by two government decrees adopted on February 15 -- raises moderate concerns regarding the balance between executive decree-making and parliamentary legislative oversight. While the substance of the transposition is sound and advances Montenegro's accession trajectory, the Ministry of Justice notes that the legal architecture must ensure adequate judicial review mechanisms, anti-corruption safeguards in the energy sector, and full compliance with constitutional procedures for delegated legislation.
assessments.executive_summary: The Ministry of Justice views Montenegro's completion of the EU electricity market integration package transposition positively as it advances EU legal harmonization. However, key concerns include the reliance on government decrees rather than full parliamentary legislation for critical components, the need for stronger anti-corruption safeguards in the energy sector, and ensuring that the new regulatory framework includes adequate judicial review mechanisms consistent with rule of law standards.
assessments.reasoning:
Montenegro's completion of the electricity market integration package transposition represents meaningful progress in aligning domestic legislation with the EU acquis, which is a central objective of the accession process. The Energy Community Secretariat's confirmation that Montenegro is the third contracting party to complete this process -- after Serbia and Moldova -- underscores the country's commitment to regulatory convergence.

From a constitutional compliance standpoint, the legislative architecture appears to follow proper procedure: the foundational laws (the Energy Law and the Cross-border Electricity and Natural Gas Exchange Law) were adopted through parliamentary process, while the two supplementary decrees on system operations and emergency situations were adopted by the Government on February 15, 2026. Under Articles 100 and 101 of the Montenegrin Constitution, the Government has the power to adopt decrees and decisions for the enforcement of laws. However, the Ministry of Justice notes that the scope and substance of these decrees must remain within the bounds of the enabling legislation and must not encroach on matters that require primary legislation. The Constitution reserves to Parliament the power to adopt laws, and delegated legislation must not exceed the mandate granted by the parent statute.

Regarding the rule of law, the new legal framework must incorporate effective judicial review mechanisms. Market participants affected by regulatory decisions under the new framework -- including those related to market access, capacity allocation, and emergency measures -- must have recourse to independent courts. This is particularly important given that Montenegro's Energy Regulatory Agency (REGAGEN) will be making consequential decisions affecting market actors, and the right to an effective remedy is guaranteed under Article 20 of the Montenegrin Constitution and Article 13 of the European Convention on Human Rights.

On anti-corruption, the energy sector in Montenegro has historically been vulnerable to corruption risks, given the dominant role of state-owned EPCG and the significant financial flows involved in electricity market operations. The EU's 2025 Progress Report for Montenegro noted that comprehensive anti-corruption legislation is not always matched with practical enforcement. As Montenegro opens its electricity market to cross-border integration with the EU's Single Day-Ahead and Intraday Markets, the volume of transactions and the complexity of market operations will increase substantially. This creates both opportunities for greater transparency through EU-standard market rules and risks of new corruption vectors if oversight mechanisms are insufficient. The Agency for Prevention of Corruption (ASK) and the Special State Prosecutor's Office must be equipped to monitor and investigate irregularities in this domain.

With respect to EU harmonization, this decision directly supports Montenegro's accession process, though it primarily falls under energy chapters rather than Chapter 23. Nevertheless, the Ministry of Justice observes that credible rule of law reform under Chapters 23 and 24 creates the institutional foundation that makes technical harmonization in sectors like energy meaningful. The European Commission's verification process -- which is a precondition for Montenegro's actual market access -- will assess not only technical transposition but also the quality of implementation and enforcement, which depends on judicial and institutional capacity. Montenegro adopted action plans for final benchmarks in Chapters 23 and 24 with a deadline of Q3 2026, and demonstrating that transposed legislation is backed by effective enforcement and judicial oversight would strengthen Montenegro's case for closing these critical chapters.

The decision also has implications for human rights in a broader sense: secure, competitive, and well-regulated energy supply is linked to the right to an adequate standard of living. Emergency situation provisions in the adopted decrees must comply with constitutional protections and ensure that any emergency measures affecting consumers or market participants are proportionate, time-limited, and subject to judicial review.

In summary, while this is primarily an energy policy achievement, the Ministry of Justice recognizes its significance within the broader EU integration framework and identifies specific areas where legal safeguards must be reinforced to ensure the new framework operates consistently with constitutional principles and rule of law standards.
key_concerns: The two government decrees on system operations and emergency situations were adopted by executive action rather than parliamentary legislation, raising questions about the scope of delegated powers and whether adequate parliamentary scrutiny was applied to these measures.

The emergency situations decree must include proportionality safeguards and judicial review mechanisms to prevent executive overreach during energy crises, consistent with constitutional protections under Article 20 of the Montenegrin Constitution.

Montenegro's energy sector faces persistent corruption risks given the dominant market position of state-owned EPCG. Increased cross-border market integration will create new financial flows requiring enhanced oversight by the Agency for Prevention of Corruption and the Special State Prosecutor.

The Energy Regulatory Agency (REGAGEN) will exercise expanded decision-making powers under the new framework, and its decisions must be subject to effective and independent judicial review by competent courts.

The verification process by the Energy Community Secretariat and European Commission must assess not just formal transposition but substantive implementation quality, including enforcement capacity and access to justice for affected parties.
Parliamentary oversight of the implementation phase is not clearly defined, and there is a risk that technical complexity will shield executive action from adequate legislative scrutiny.
recommendations: The Government should present the two adopted decrees to the relevant parliamentary committee (Committee for Economy, Finance and Budget or Committee for European Integration) for ex-post scrutiny, ensuring transparency and democratic legitimacy.

The Ministry of Justice should conduct a constitutional compliance review of the emergency situations decree to verify that any emergency powers granted are proportionate, time-limited, and include mandatory judicial review provisions.

The Agency for Prevention of Corruption (ASK) should be tasked with developing a specific risk assessment for corruption vulnerabilities arising from cross-border electricity market integration, including conflicts of interest in regulatory bodies.

The Energy Regulatory Agency's decisions under the new framework should be subject to appeal before the Administrative Court, with clear procedural rules and reasonable timelines to ensure effective judicial protection.

Montenegro should establish a transparent public reporting mechanism for the implementation phase, publishing progress reports on the verification process and any compliance gaps identified by the Energy Community Secretariat.

The Government should ensure that the Law on Cross-border Electricity and Natural Gas Exchange includes whistleblower protection provisions for individuals reporting irregularities in energy market operations, consistent with the EU Whistleblower Directive.

counter_proposal.title: Rule of Law Safeguards for Energy Market Integration
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Justice would supplement the current transposition approach with a dedicated legal safeguards package ensuring that the energy market integration framework operates within robust rule of law parameters. Rather than relying primarily on government decrees for critical operational and emergency provisions, we would propose that key elements be elevated to primary legislation with explicit judicial review clauses, anti-corruption provisions, and parliamentary oversight mechanisms built into the legislative text itself.
key_changes: Elevate the most consequential provisions of the two government decrees -- particularly those governing emergency situations and any powers that restrict market participants' rights -- into primary legislation subject to full parliamentary debate.

Insert explicit judicial review clauses into the Energy Law and Cross-border Exchange Law, specifying that all regulatory decisions by REGAGEN and the transmission system operator are subject to appeal before the Administrative Court within 30 days.
Mandate that the Agency for Prevention of Corruption conduct annual integrity assessments of the energy market regulatory framework, with findings reported to Parliament.
Establish a dedicated parliamentary monitoring mechanism (sub-committee or reporting requirement) for the Energy Community verification and implementation process.
Include mandatory conflict-of-interest disclosure requirements for all officials and board members involved in cross-border electricity market operations.
expected_benefits: Stronger democratic legitimacy and constitutional compliance by ensuring that provisions affecting fundamental rights and market access are adopted through primary legislation.
Enhanced investor confidence through clear, independent judicial review pathways for regulatory decisions.
Reduced corruption risk in a sector historically vulnerable to governance failures, supporting Montenegro's Chapter 23 reform objectives.
Better alignment with EU rule of law expectations, strengthening Montenegro's position in the verification process and broader accession negotiations.
Improved public trust through transparent parliamentary oversight of a technically complex but economically significant integration process.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High feasibility. The proposed changes are complementary to the existing legislative framework and would not delay the verification process. Parliamentary committee review can proceed in parallel with the Energy Community Secretariat's assessment. The anti-corruption risk assessment by ASK and judicial review provisions are consistent with existing institutional mandates and would require only incremental legislative amendments rather than a fundamental restructuring of the transposition approach.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Garancije vladavine prava za integraciju tržišta energije
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Ministarstvo pravde bi dopunilo trenutni pristup transpozicije namjenskim paketom pravnih garancija, osiguravajući da okvir za integraciju tržišta energije funkcioniše u okviru čvrstih parametara vladavine prava. Umjesto da se primarno oslanja na vladine uredbe za ključne operativne odredbe i odredbe za vanredne situacije, predložili bismo da se ključni elementi uzdignу do primarne legislative s izričitim klauzulama o sudskom preispitivanju, odredbama za borbu protiv korupcije i mehanizmima parlamentarnog nadzora ugrađenim u sam zakonodavni tekst.
key_changes_mne: Uzdizanje najvažnijih odredbi dviju vladinih uredbi -- posebno onih kojima se uređuju vanredne situacije i ovlašćenja koja ograničavaju prava učesnika na tržištu -- u primarnu legislativu koja podliježe punoj parlamentarnoj raspravi.

Umetanje izričitih klauzula o sudskom preispitivanju u Zakon o energetici i Zakon o prekograničnoj razmjeni, kojima se precizira da sve regulatorne odluke REGAGEN-a i operatora prenosnog sistema podliježu žalbi pred Upravnim sudom u roku od 30 dana.
Obavezivanje Agencije za sprječavanje korupcije da sprovodi godišnje procjene integriteta regulatornog okvira tržišta energije, s nalazima koji se dostavljaju Parlamentu.
Uspostavljanje namjenskog mehanizma parlamentarnog praćenja (pododbora ili obaveze izvještavanja) za proces verifikacije i implementacije u okviru Energetske zajednice.
Uvođenje obaveznih zahtjeva za obelodanjivanje sukoba interesa za sve funkcionere i članove odbora uključene u operacije prekograničnog tržišta električne energije.
expected_benefits_mne: Jači demokratski legitimitet i ustavna usklađenost, osiguravanjem da se odredbe koje utiču na osnovna prava i pristup tržištu usvajaju putem primarne legislative.
Pojačano povjerenje investitora zahvaljujući jasnim i nezavisnim putevima sudskog preispitivanja regulatornih odluka.
Smanjen rizik od korupcije u sektoru historijski podložnom slabostima u upravljanju, čime se podržavaju ciljevi reformi Crne Gore u okviru Poglavlja 23.
Bolje usklađivanje s EU očekivanjima u pogledu vladavine prava, čime se jača pozicija Crne Gore u procesu verifikacije i širim pregovorima o pristupanju.
Unaprijeđeno javno povjerenje kroz transparentan parlamentarni nadzor nad tehnički složenim, ali ekonomski značajnim procesom integracije.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka izvodljivost. Predložene izmjene komplementarne su postojećem zakonodavnom okviru i ne bi odložile proces verifikacije. Pregled od strane parlamentarnog odbora može teći paralelno s procjenom Sekretarijata Energetske zajednice. Procjena rizika od korupcije od strane ASK-a i odredbe o sudskom preispitivanju u skladu su s postojećim institucionalnim mandatima i zahtijevale bi samo postupne zakonodavne izmjene, a ne temeljno restrukturiranje pristupa transpoziciji.

assessments.summary_mne: Završetak transpozicije paketa integracije tržišta električne energije EU predstavlja dobrodošao korak u širem procesu harmonizacije Crne Gore sa EU, čime se demonstrira kapacitet Vlade da uskladi domaće zakonodavstvo sa acquis communautaire EU. Sa stanovišta pravde, zakonodavni okvir — koji obuhvata Zakon o energetici i Zakon o prekograničnoj razmjeni električne energije i prirodnog gasa, usvojene u Parlamentu, dopunjene dvjema uredbama Vlade usvojenim 15. februara — izaziva umjerene zabrinutosti u pogledu ravnoteže između izvršnog donošenja uredbi i parlamentarnog zakonodavnog nadzora. Iako je suština transpozicije valjana i unapređuje pristupnu trajektoriju Crne Gore, Ministarstvo pravde napominje da pravna arhitektura mora osigurati adekvatne mehanizme sudske kontrole, antikorupcijske zaštitne mjere u energetskom sektoru i potpunu usklađenost s ustavnim postupcima za delegirano zakonodavstvo.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ministarstvo pravde pozitivno ocjenjuje završetak transpozicije paketa integracije tržišta električne energije EU od strane Crne Gore, budući da se njime unapređuje pravna harmonizacija sa EU. Međutim, ključne zabrinutosti odnose se na oslanjanje na vladine uredbe umjesto na cjelovito parlamentarno zakonodavstvo za kritične komponente, na potrebu za jačim antikorupcijskim zaštitnim mjerama u energetskom sektoru, kao i na osiguranje da novi regulatorni okvir uključuje adekvatne mehanizme sudske kontrole, u skladu sa standardima vladavine prava.
key_concerns_mne: Dvije vladine uredbe o upravljanju sistemom i vanrednim situacijama usvojene su izvršnom akcijom, a ne parlamentarnim zakonodavstvom, što dovodi u pitanje obim delegiranih ovlašćenja i da li je ovim mjerama primijenjen adekvatan parlamentarni nadzor.

Uredba o vanrednim situacijama mora sadržati zaštitne mjere proporcionalnosti i mehanizme sudske kontrole kako bi se spriječilo prekoračenje izvršnih ovlašćenja tokom energetskih kriza, u skladu s ustavnim zaštitama predviđenim članom 20 Ustava Crne Gore.

Energetski sektor Crne Gore suočen je s trajnim rizicima od korupcije imajući u vidu dominantan tržišni položaj državnog preduzeća EPCG. Pojačana integracija prekograničnog tržišta stvoriće nove finansijske tokove koji zahtijevaju pojačani nadzor Agencije za sprječavanje korupcije i Specijalnog državnog tužilaštva.

Agencija za energetiku (REGAGEN) vršiće proširena ovlašćenja odlučivanja u okviru novog normativnog okvira, a njene odluke moraju biti podložne djelotvornoj i nezavisnoj sudskoj kontroli od strane nadležnih sudova.

Proces verifikacije od strane Sekretarijata Energetske zajednice i Evropske komisije mora procjenjivati ne samo formalnu transpoziciju, već i kvalitet suštinske primjene, uključujući kapacitete za sprovođenje i pristup pravdi za pogođene strane.
Parlamentarni nadzor nad fazom implementacije nije jasno definisan, a postoji rizik da će tehnička složenost zaštititi izvršne aktivnosti od adekvatnog zakonodavnog preispitivanja.
recommendations_mne: Vlada bi trebalo da podnese dvije usvojene uredbe nadležnom parlamentarnom odboru (Odboru za ekonomiju, finansije i budžet ili Odboru za evropske integracije) radi naknadnog preispitivanja, čime se osigurava transparentnost i demokratski legitimitet.

Ministarstvo pravde trebalo bi da sprovede pregled ustavne usklađenosti uredbe o vanrednim situacijama kako bi se utvrdilo da su sva dodijeljena vanredna ovlašćenja proporcionalna, vremenski ograničena i da uključuju obavezne odredbe o sudskoj kontroli.

Agencija za sprječavanje korupcije (ASK) trebalo bi da dobije zadatak izrade posebne procjene rizika od korupcije koja proistječe iz integracije prekograničnog tržišta električne energije, uključujući sukobe interesa u regulatornim tijelima.

Odluke Agencije za energetiku u okviru novog normativnog okvira moraju biti podložne žalbi pred Upravnim sudom, uz jasna proceduralna pravila i razumne rokove koji osiguravaju djelotvornu sudsku zaštitu.

Crna Gora treba da uspostavi transparentan mehanizam javnog izvještavanja za fazu implementacije, objavljivanjem izvještaja o napretku u procesu verifikacije i svim utvrđenim nedostacima u usklađenosti koje identifikuje Sekretarijat Energetske zajednice.

Vlada treba da osigura da Zakon o prekograničnoj razmjeni električne energije i prirodnog gasa uključuje odredbe o zaštiti uzbunjivača za lica koja prijavljuju nepravilnosti u poslovanju na tržištu energije, u skladu sa Direktivom EU o zaštiti uzbunjivača.

assessments.summary: The completion of the EU electricity market integration package transposition is a positive development for healthcare from the perspective of energy security and long-term supply stability, though the Ministry of Health notes that the transition carries medium-term risks of electricity price increases that could strain already underfunded healthcare facilities. Montenegro's hospitals, particularly the aging Clinical Center of Montenegro in Podgorica, are major energy consumers, and the June 2024 regional blackout demonstrated the vulnerability of health infrastructure to grid failures. Integration with SDAC and SIDC markets should improve supply reliability and reduce blackout risks, but the shift from heavily subsidized domestic electricity pricing toward EU market rates requires proactive planning to shield healthcare institutions from cost shocks.
assessments.executive_summary: EU electricity market integration is broadly positive for health sector energy security and aligns with ongoing EBRD-funded hospital energy efficiency investments, but the Ministry of Health warns that anticipated electricity price increases could burden an already strained healthcare budget where out-of-pocket spending is 38% of total health expenditure. The Ministry recommends that healthcare facilities be designated as protected consumers during the price transition period and that hospital energy efficiency renovations be accelerated.
assessments.reasoning: Montenegro's decision to complete transposition of the Energy Community's electricity market integration package has several indirect but significant implications for the healthcare sector. First, regarding energy security for health facilities: the June 2024 cascading blackout that hit Montenegro, Albania, Bosnia-Herzegovina, and Croatia's Dalmatian coast affected approximately 4 million people and forced hospitals to switch to emergency generators. Integration into the EU's Single Day-Ahead Market and Single Intraday Market should strengthen grid stability by enabling cross-border balancing and reducing the risk of such cascading failures. This is directly relevant to patient safety, as power interruptions threaten life-support systems, surgical operations, cold-chain integrity for pharmaceuticals and blood products, and diagnostic equipment functionality. Second, the price dimension is critical. According to OECD data, Montenegro accumulated EUR 1.16 billion in induced energy support to consumers between 2018-2023, with EUR 632 million during the 2022 energy crisis alone, representing 10.7% of GDP. Current household electricity tariffs of approximately 0.09 EUR per kWh for the daily rate are well below EU averages. As market integration proceeds and coal-generated electricity (over 40% of Montenegro's supply) is priced closer to its full cost including emissions, upward price pressure is inevitable. Healthcare facilities are among the largest institutional energy consumers. The Clinical Center of Montenegro in Podgorica, built over 50 years ago, has outdated heating, ventilation, and insulation systems. A EUR 12 million EBRD and EU-supported loan for energy efficiency renovations at the Clinical Center, General Hospital Cetinje, and General Hospital Bijelo Polje aims to reduce energy consumption by 50%, but this project is still in early implementation. Until these renovations are complete, higher energy costs will directly increase hospital operating expenses, potentially diverting funds from clinical care, medical supplies, and staff compensation. Third, there is a fiscal channel: Montenegro's health expenditure has risen above 10% of GDP post-pandemic, and the Health Insurance Fund operates under tight constraints. If the government must reduce energy subsidies as part of market liberalization, and if healthcare facility energy bills rise significantly, this creates additional pressure on a system already characterized by high out-of-pocket payments (38% of current health spending in 2021, per WHO data), long wait times, and chronic health workforce shortages driven by brain drain to EU countries. The Ministry notes that the decision is fundamentally sound from an EU accession standpoint and aligns with Chapter 28 requirements on consumer and health protection, which include energy market provisions that protect vulnerable consumers. However, the implementing legislation must ensure that healthcare facilities and vulnerable patient populations are explicitly protected during the transition period.
key_concerns: Electricity price increases resulting from market liberalization could raise operating costs for Montenegro's 18 public healthcare facilities before energy efficiency renovations are completed

The June 2024 regional blackout exposed critical vulnerabilities in hospital backup power systems; while market integration should improve grid stability, the transition period may create new supply volatility
Healthcare budget pressure: if energy subsidies are reduced, hospitals may face difficult trade-offs between paying higher utility bills and funding clinical services, pharmaceuticals, and staff

The EBRD-funded EUR 12 million hospital energy efficiency renovation program needs to be accelerated to coincide with market integration timelines, as the Clinical Center of Montenegro's aging infrastructure makes it highly energy-inefficient
Vulnerable patients who depend on home-based medical equipment (oxygen concentrators, dialysis machines, ventilators) face both affordability and reliability risks during the energy price transition
No explicit health sector impact assessment appears to have been conducted as part of the transposition process
recommendations: Designate all public healthcare facilities as protected consumers under the new energy legal framework, ensuring priority supply restoration and price stabilization mechanisms during the market transition

Accelerate the EBRD-EU hospital energy efficiency renovation program to complete major works at the Clinical Center and general hospitals before full market coupling takes effect in late 2026 or early 2027

Conduct a health sector energy audit across all 18 public healthcare facilities to identify critical infrastructure vulnerabilities and prioritize investments in backup power systems, particularly for ICUs, operating theaters, and pharmaceutical cold chains

Coordinate with the Ministry of Energy to ensure that the government's social protection measures for vulnerable consumers explicitly cover patients dependent on electricity-powered home medical equipment

Establish an energy cost monitoring mechanism within the Health Insurance Fund (RFZO successor) to track the impact of electricity price changes on healthcare facility operating budgets and trigger compensatory budget adjustments
Include a health impact assessment requirement in all future energy market regulatory changes, consistent with EU Health in All Policies principles under Chapter 28 alignment

counter_proposal.title: Health-Proofed Energy Market Integration
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Health supports the electricity market integration but proposes that the implementation phase include explicit healthcare sector safeguards. Rather than treating energy market reform and healthcare infrastructure as separate policy tracks, the Ministry would require a mandatory health impact assessment for all energy pricing and subsidy reform measures, accelerate hospital energy efficiency investments to precede market coupling, and establish a dedicated energy cost buffer within the healthcare budget to absorb price transition shocks over a 3-year period.
key_changes: Mandate health impact assessments for all energy regulatory changes adopted under the new Energy Law and Cross-Border Electricity Exchange Law
Fast-track the EBRD hospital renovation timeline from current schedule to completion before SDAC/SIDC market coupling goes live
Create a 3-year Healthcare Energy Transition Fund (estimated EUR 2-3 million annually) within the health budget to absorb electricity cost increases at public health facilities
Include home medical equipment users in the definition of vulnerable consumers eligible for energy price protection under the new decrees on emergency situations
Require all public hospitals to have certified backup power systems capable of sustaining full operations for minimum 72 hours, aligned with EU hospital resilience standards
expected_benefits: Healthcare facilities would be insulated from energy price shocks during the critical 2026-2029 transition period, preventing service quality deterioration
Accelerated energy efficiency renovations would reduce long-term hospital operating costs by up to 50% as demonstrated by the EBRD project design
Vulnerable patients on home medical equipment would have explicit legal protection against supply interruptions and unaffordable energy costs
Montenegro would demonstrate EU-aligned Health in All Policies governance, strengthening the Chapter 28 negotiating position
Improved hospital backup power infrastructure would enhance disaster preparedness and patient safety
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High feasibility. The proposed measures are incremental additions to existing policy frameworks rather than new programs. The Healthcare Energy Transition Fund of EUR 2-3 million annually is modest relative to overall health spending (approximately 10% of GDP). Hospital energy efficiency acceleration depends on EBRD project management capacity but is technically straightforward. The main political challenge is inter-ministerial coordination between Health and Energy ministries, which requires Prime Minister-level direction.

assessments.summary_mne: Završetak transpozicije paketa o integraciji EU tržišta električne energije predstavlja pozitivan razvoj za zdravstvo iz perspektive energetske bezbjednosti i dugoročne stabilnosti snabdijevanja, iako Ministarstvo zdravlja napominje da tranzicija nosi srednjoročne rizike od rasta cijena električne energije koji bi mogli dodatno opteretiti ionako nedovoljno finansirana zdravstvena ustanova. Crnogorske bolnice, posebno zastarjeli Klinički centar Crne Gore u Podgorici, veliki su potrošači energije, a regionalni nestanak struje u junu 2024. godine pokazao je koliko je zdravstvena infrastruktura ranjiva na kvarove mreže. Integracija sa tržištima SDAC i SIDC trebalo bi da poboljša pouzdanost snabdijevanja i smanji rizike od nestanka struje, ali prelazak sa visoko subvencionisanih domaćih cijena električne energije na cijene EU tržišta zahtijeva proaktivno planiranje kako bi se zdravstvene ustanove zaštitile od cjenovnih šokova.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Integracija EU tržišta električne energije u širem smislu je pozitivna za energetsku bezbjednost zdravstvenog sektora i usklađena je sa tekućim investicijama u energetsku efikasnost bolnica koje finansira EBRD, ali Ministarstvo zdravlja upozorava da bi anticipirani rast cijena električne energije mogao opteretiti ionako opterećeni zdravstveni budžet u kome direktno plaćanje iz džepa iznosi 38% ukupnih zdravstvenih rashoda. Ministarstvo preporučuje da zdravstvene ustanove budu proglašene zaštićenim kupcima tokom perioda tranzicije cijena i da se renovacije bolnica radi povećanja energetske efikasnosti ubrzaju.
key_concerns_mne: Rast cijena električne energije usljed liberalizacije tržišta mogao bi povećati troškove poslovanja za 18 javnih zdravstvenih ustanova u Crnoj Gori prije nego što budu završene renovacije radi povećanja energetske efikasnosti

Regionalni nestanak struje u junu 2024. godine otkrio je kritične ranjivosti u sistemima rezervnog napajanja bolnica; iako bi integracija tržišta trebalo da poboljša stabilnost mreže, period tranzicije može stvoriti novu nestabilnost u snabdijevanju

Pritisak na zdravstveni budžet: ukoliko se energetske subvencije smanje, bolnice bi se mogle naći pred teškim izborom između plaćanja viših računa za komunalne usluge i finansiranja kliničkih usluga, lijekova i osoblja

Program renovacije bolnica radi povećanja energetske efikasnosti, finansiran od strane EBRD-a u iznosu od 12 miliona EUR, mora biti ubrzan kako bi se uskladio sa rokovima integracije tržišta, s obzirom na to da zastarjela infrastruktura Kliničkog centra Crne Gore čini ovu ustanovu izuzetno neenergetski efikasnom

Ranjivi pacijenti koji zavise od medicinske opreme koja se koristi kod kuće (koncentratori kiseonika, aparati za dijalizu, respiratori) suočavaju se i sa rizicima dostupnosti i sa rizicima pouzdanosti tokom tranzicije cijena energije
Čini se da u okviru procesa transpozicije nije sprovedena nikakva eksplicitna procjena uticaja na zdravstveni sektor
recommendations_mne: Proglasiti sve javne zdravstvene ustanove zaštićenim kupcima u okviru novog pravnog okvira u oblasti energetike, čime se osigurava prioritetno uspostavljanje snabdijevanja i mehanizmi stabilizacije cijena tokom tržišne tranzicije

assessments.decision_id: Montenegro Completes EU Electricity Market Integration Package Transposition
assessments.summary: Montenegro's completion of the Electricity Integration Package transposition is one of the most consequential EU-alignment achievements in recent months. It directly advances Chapter 15 (Energy) closing benchmarks, positions Montenegro as a regional leader among Western Balkans candidate countries, and opens a concrete pathway to join the EU's Single Day-Ahead and Intraday electricity markets before formal accession. The decision also has critical downstream implications for avoiding hundreds of millions of euros in annual CBAM costs on electricity exports once market coupling with Italy is operationalized, expected around 2028. This is a model example of how acquis transposition can deliver tangible economic benefits well ahead of membership.
assessments.executive_summary: This decision is strongly positive for Montenegro's EU integration trajectory. Completing the Electricity Integration Package transposition advances Chapter 15 closing benchmarks and positions Montenegro to join EU electricity markets before accession, potentially shielding the country from an estimated EUR 190-350 million in annual CBAM costs. The Ministry recommends accelerating the verification process and ensuring robust implementation capacity to convert this legislative achievement into actual market coupling by the 2028 target.
assessments.reasoning:
From the EU integration perspective, this decision merits the highest level of praise for several interconnected reasons. First, on acquis alignment: Chapter 15 (Energy) was opened in December 2015 and its closing benchmarks require Montenegro to comply with the internal energy market acquis, including unbundling of energy entities and full legislative alignment. The adoption of the Energy Law, the Cross-border Electricity and Natural Gas Exchange Law, and the two February 15 government decrees on system operations and emergency situations represents the most extensive reform of Montenegro's energy legislation in the past decade. This directly satisfies key closing benchmarks under Chapter 15 and signals to the European Commission that Montenegro is serious about meeting the ambitious goal of closing all negotiation chapters by end of 2026. As of January 2026, Montenegro has provisionally closed 13 of 33 chapters, meaning significant acceleration is needed; Chapter 15 progress strengthens the case for its eventual closure.

Second, the regional dimension is significant. Montenegro is only the third Energy Community contracting party to complete this transposition, after Serbia and Moldova. This places Montenegro ahead of Albania, North Macedonia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Kosovo in electricity market integration readiness. Being a frontrunner in transposition strengthens Montenegro's negotiating credibility with Brussels and can be cited in the European Commission's annual progress report as concrete evidence of reform commitment.

Third, the economic implications are enormous due to the CBAM (Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism) connection. CBAM entered full force in January 2026, and Montenegro faces estimated annual costs of EUR 190-350 million on electricity exports to the EU. The only pathway to an electricity CBAM exemption runs through market coupling, which requires completed transposition and verification. While full coupling with Italy via the SDAC is not expected before Q1 2028, completing transposition now puts Montenegro on the fastest possible track. Every month of delay in this process translates to substantial financial exposure.

Fourth, regarding IPA funding and investment framework implications, the transposition creates a clearer regulatory environment for EU-funded energy infrastructure projects. Montenegro benefits from PECI-labelled projects under IPA III, including transmission capacity upgrades and the Trans-Balkan Corridor. A fully transposed energy market framework strengthens the case for additional IPA allocations and WBIF investment support during the 2024-2027 programming period.

The only qualification to this otherwise excellent assessment is that transposition alone is insufficient. The Energy Community's 2025 Implementation Report noted that Montenegro had achieved only limited progress in implementing the Action Plan for Chapter 15 closing benchmarks. The gap between legislative adoption and effective implementation remains a persistent concern across Montenegro's EU integration process. Serbia is already undergoing verification by the European Commission, and Montenegro must move swiftly to submit its own verification request and build the institutional capacity needed to operationalize these new rules.
key_concerns: Implementation gap: transposition is complete but the 2025 Energy Community Implementation Report flagged only limited progress on the broader Chapter 15 action plan, suggesting institutional capacity may lag behind legislative ambition.

Verification timeline uncertainty: the European Commission and Energy Community Secretariat verification process has no guaranteed timeline, and delays could push actual market coupling beyond the Q1 2028 target for the Italy-Montenegro border.

CBAM exposure window: with CBAM fully operational since January 2026 and market coupling unlikely before 2028, Montenegro faces at least two years of significant carbon border costs on electricity exports estimated at EUR 190-350 million annually.

Institutional readiness: the Montenegrin Power Exchange (MEPX) and the transmission system operator (CGES) must develop operational capacity to participate in SDAC and SIDC mechanisms, requiring technical expertise, IT infrastructure, and regulatory coordination that goes well beyond legal transposition.
Risk of legislative achievement being cited as sufficient progress while substantive implementation lags, a pattern observed in multiple negotiation chapters in Montenegro's accession process.
recommendations: Immediately submit the formal verification request to the Energy Community Secretariat and European Commission, with a target of initiating the verification process within 30 days of the February 21 announcement.

Establish a dedicated cross-ministerial implementation task force linking the Ministry of Energy, the energy regulatory authority, CGES, and MEPX to ensure operational readiness matches legislative alignment.

Leverage this achievement in the next Intergovernmental Conference to demonstrate concrete Chapter 15 progress and advocate for provisional closure of the chapter, potentially as part of the cluster of chapters targeted for closure in 2026.

Actively engage with European Commission and Italian counterparts (ARERA, Terna, GME) to maintain the Q1 2028 timeline for Italy-Montenegro day-ahead market coupling, as any delay extends CBAM cost exposure.

Request targeted IPA III technical assistance for building MEPX and CGES operational capacity for SDAC and SIDC participation, and for training regulatory staff on EU internal energy market methodologies.
Coordinate with Serbia (which is already in the verification phase) to share experiences and potentially accelerate Montenegro's own verification process through lessons learned.

Use this legislative milestone to strengthen Montenegro's position in ongoing CBAM discussions, advocating for a transitional exemption or phased application for electricity from countries that have completed transposition and are in the verification pipeline.

counter_proposal.title: Accelerated Implementation and Verification Strategy
counter_proposal.summary: While the transposition decision itself is excellent and requires no legislative alternative, the Ministry of EU Integration would complement it with an aggressive implementation acceleration strategy. Rather than treating transposition as a completed milestone, we would embed it within a comprehensive Chapter 15 closure roadmap that links verification, operational readiness, CBAM mitigation, and IPA utilization into a single coordinated effort with clear deadlines and accountability mechanisms.
key_changes: Establish a formal 90-day implementation action plan with measurable milestones for verification submission, MEPX technical readiness, and CGES operational protocols, reported to the Council for the Rule of Law.
Assign a dedicated Chapter 15 chief negotiator with direct authority to coordinate between energy institutions, the EU integration office, and Italian counterparts on the market coupling timeline.

Commission an independent CBAM impact assessment specific to Montenegro's energy mix and export profile, quantifying the financial case for expedited market coupling and using it in advocacy with the European Commission for transitional relief.

Integrate this energy market achievement into a broader 'quick wins' communication strategy for the EU accession process, demonstrating to Brussels and to Montenegrin citizens that accession delivers tangible pre-membership benefits.

Propose at the next Energy Community Ministerial Council that contracting parties that have completed transposition and are in verification should receive interim CBAM relief, building a coalition with Serbia and Moldova.
expected_benefits: Faster progression from transposition to actual market coupling, potentially accelerating the Italy-Montenegro go-live date.
Reduced CBAM financial exposure through both faster coupling and advocacy for transitional exemptions.
Strengthened Chapter 15 closure case for the next Intergovernmental Conference.
Better absorption of IPA III and WBIF funds through a clear regulatory and institutional framework.
Demonstration effect for other negotiation chapters that legislative reform can be quickly followed by effective implementation.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High. The legislative foundation is already in place. The proposed changes are primarily organizational, coordination-focused, and advocacy-oriented, requiring political will and institutional coordination rather than new legislation or significant additional funding. The main constraint is the limited pool of energy regulatory experts in Montenegro, which can be partially addressed through IPA-funded technical assistance.
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Iako je sama odluka o transpoziciji odlična i ne zahtijeva zakonodavnu alternativu, Ministarstvo evropskih integracija bi je dopunilo agresivnom strategijom ubrzanja implementacije. Umjesto da se transpozicija tretira kao završena prekretnica, ugradili bismo je u sveobuhvatnu mapu puta za zatvaranje Poglavlja 15, koja povezuje verifikaciju, operativnu spremnost, ublažavanje CBAM-a i korišćenje IPA fondova u jedan koordinisan napor s jasnim rokovima i mehanizmima odgovornosti.
key_changes_mne: Uspostavljanje formalnog akcionog plana implementacije od 90 dana s mjerljivim prekretnicama za podnošenje verifikacije, tehničku spremnost MEPX-a i operativne protokole CGES-a, o čemu se izvještava Savjet za vladavinu prava.

Imenovanje dedicated glavnog pregovarača za Poglavlje 15 s direktnim ovlašćenjem za koordinaciju između energetskih institucija, kancelarije za evropske integracije i italijanskih partnera po pitanju vremenskog okvira tržišnog spajanja.

Naručivanje nezavisne procjene uticaja CBAM-a specifične za energetski miks i izvozni profil Crne Gore, s kvantifikacijom finansijskog argumenta za ubrzano tržišno spajanje i njenim korišćenjem u zagovaranju prema Evropskoj komisiji za privremena olakšanja.

Integrisanje ovog dostignuća na tržištu energije u širu komunikacijsku strategiju 'brzih pobjeda' za proces pristupanja EU-u, demonstrirajući Briselu i crnogorskim građanima da pristupanje donosi opipljive benefite i prije članstva.

Predlaganje na narednom Ministarskom savjetu Energetske zajednice da ugovorne strane koje su završile transpoziciju i nalaze se u fazi verifikacije dobiju privremeno olakšanje od CBAM-a, gradeći koaliciju sa Srbijom i Moldavijom.
expected_benefits_mne: Brže napredovanje od transpozicije do stvarnog tržišnog spajanja, uz potencijalno ubrzanje datuma puštanja u rad veze Italija–Crna Gora.
Smanjenje finansijske izloženosti CBAM-u kroz brže spajanje i zagovaranje za privremena izuzeća.
Ojačan slučaj za zatvaranje Poglavlja 15 na narednoj Međuvladinoj konferenciji.
Bolja apsorpcija sredstava iz IPA III i WBIF fondova kroz jasan regulatorni i institucionalni okvir.
Demonstracioni efekat za ostala pregovaračka poglavlja da zakonodavna reforma može biti brzo praćena efikasnom implementacijom.
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka. Zakonodavni temelj je već uspostavljen. Predložene izmjene su pretežno organizacionog karaktera, usmjerene na koordinaciju i zagovaranje, te zahtijevaju političku volju i institucionalnu koordinaciju, a ne novo zakonodavstvo ili značajna dodatna sredstva. Glavni ograničavajući faktor je ograničen broj stručnjaka za energetsku regulativu u Crnoj Gori, što se djelimično može riješiti tehničkom podrškom finansiranom iz IPA fondova.

assessments.summary_mne: Završetak transpozicije Paketa za integraciju električne energije u Crnoj Gori jedno je od najznačajnijih dostignuća u usklađivanju s EU-om u posljednjih nekoliko mjeseci. Direktno unapređuje referentne vrijednosti za zatvaranje Poglavlja 15 (Energetika), pozicionira Crnu Goru kao regionalnog lidera među kandidatskim zemljama Zapadnog Balkana i otvara konkretan put ka pristupanju jedinstvenim tržištima električne energije EU-a za isporuku dan unaprijed i unutar dana, prije formalnog pristupanja. Odluka ima i kritične posljedice po izbjegavanje stotina miliona eura godišnjih troškova CBAM-a na izvoz električne energije, kada bude operacionalizovano tržišno spajanje s Italijom, što se očekuje oko 2028. godine. Ovo je primjeran primjer kako transpozicija pravnih tekovina EU-a može donijeti opipljive ekonomske koristi znatno prije sticanja članstva.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ova odluka je izrazito pozitivna za trajektoriju evropske integracije Crne Gore. Završetak transpozicije Paketa za integraciju električne energije unapređuje referentne vrijednosti za zatvaranje Poglavlja 15 i pozicionira Crnu Goru da se priključi tržištima električne energije EU-a prije pristupanja, potencijalno štiteći zemlju od procijenjenih 190–350 miliona eura godišnjih troškova CBAM-a. Ministarstvo preporučuje ubrzavanje procesa verifikacije i osiguravanje snažnih implementacionih kapaciteta kako bi se ovo zakonodavno postignuće pretvorilo u stvarno tržišno spajanje do cilja 2028. godine.
key_concerns_mne: Jaz u implementaciji: transpozicija je završena, ali je Izvještaj o implementaciji Energetske zajednice za 2025. godinu ukazao na samo ograničen napredak u okviru šireg akcionog plana za Poglavlje 15, što sugerira da institucionalni kapaciteti mogu zaostajati za zakonodavnim ambicijama.

Neizvjesnost vremenskog okvira verifikacije: proces verifikacije od strane Evropske komisije i Sekretarijata Energetske zajednice nema zagarantovani rok, a kašnjenja bi mogla odgurnuti stvarno tržišno spajanje izvan cilja Q1 2028. za granicu Italija–Crna Gora.

Period izloženosti CBAM-u: s obzirom na to da je CBAM u punoj primjeni od januara 2026. godine, a tržišno spajanje se ne očekuje prije 2028., Crna Gora se suočava s najmanje dvije godine značajnih troškova karbonske granice na izvoz električne energije, procijenjenih na 190–350 miliona eura godišnje.

Institucionalna spremnost: Crnogorska berza električne energije (MEPX) i operater prenosnog sistema (CGES) moraju razviti operativne kapacitete za učešće u mehanizmima SDAC i SIDC, što zahtijeva tehničku stručnost, IT infrastrukturu i regulatornu koordinaciju koja daleko nadilazi puku zakonsku transpoziciju.
Rizik da se zakonodavno postignuće navodi kao dovoljan napredak dok suštinska implementacija zaostaje — obrazac koji je primijećen u više pregovaračkih poglavlja u procesu pristupanja Crne Gore.
recommendations_mne: Odmah podnijeti formalni zahtjev za verifikaciju Sekretarijatu Energetske zajednice i Evropskoj komisiji, s ciljem pokretanja procesa verifikacije u roku od 30 dana od najave od 21. februara.

Uspostaviti posebnu međuresornu radnu grupu za implementaciju koja će povezivati Ministarstvo energetike, regulatorni organ za energetiku, CGES i MEPX, kako bi se osiguralo da operativna spremnost prati zakonodavno usklađivanje.

Iskoristiti ovo postignuće na narednoj Međuvladinoj konferenciji radi demonstriranja konkretnog napretka u Poglavlju 15 i zagovaranja privremenog zatvaranja poglavlja, potencijalno u okviru klastera poglavlja predviđenih za zatvaranje u 2026. godini.

Aktivno sarađivati s Evropskom komisijom i italijanskim partnerima (ARERA, Terna, GME) radi održavanja vremenskog okvira Q1 2028. za tržišno spajanje dan unaprijed na granici Italija–Crna Gora, budući da svako kašnjenje produžava izloženost troškovima CBAM-a.

Zatražiti ciljanu tehničku pomoć u okviru IPA III radi izgradnje operativnih kapaciteta MEPX-a i CGES-a za učešće u SDAC-u i SIDC-u, kao i za obuku regulatornog osoblja u metodologijama unutrašnjeg tržišta električne energije EU-a.
Koordinisati se sa Srbijom (koja se već nalazi u fazi verifikacije) radi razmjene iskustava i potencijalnog ubrzavanja sopstvenog procesa verifikacije kroz stečene pouke.

Iskoristiti ovaj zakonodavni prekretnicu radi jačanja pozicije Crne Gore u tekućim raspravama o CBAM-u, zagovarajući prelazno izuzeće ili postupnu primjenu za električnu energiju iz zemalja koje su završile transpoziciju i nalaze se u procesu verifikacije.

assessments.summary: Montenegro's completion of the electricity market integration package transposition is a landmark achievement for economic development and competitiveness. By becoming the third Energy Community contracting party to complete this process, Montenegro has positioned itself to join the EU's Single Day-Ahead Market (SDAC) and Single Intraday Market (SIDC) before formal EU accession, primarily through the existing 600 MW Italy-Montenegro HVDC submarine cable. This decision sends clear investment signals, strengthens energy security, aligns with EU accession requirements, and can catalyze renewable energy investment. However, the Ministry notes that market coupling with EU prices carries risks of upward price pressure on domestic industrial consumers and households, and the benefits will only materialize if implementation and verification proceed without delay.
assessments.executive_summary: This is one of the most consequential economic policy achievements in Montenegro's EU integration path, unlocking access to the EU's integrated electricity market through the Italy-Montenegro interconnector and sending strong signals to energy investors. The top concern is that price convergence with higher EU electricity markets could increase costs for domestic industry and SMEs unless mitigated by expanded renewable capacity and targeted support. The Ministry recommends an urgent parallel track on industrial energy competitiveness measures and accelerated renewable deployment to ensure market integration benefits the real economy.
assessments.reasoning:
Montenegro's completion of the electricity market integration package transposition represents a structural economic reform of the highest order. The decision encompasses the Energy Law and the newly adopted Cross-border Electricity and Natural Gas Exchange Law, along with two government decrees on system operations and emergency situations adopted on February 15, 2026. This legal architecture aligns Montenegro with EU acquis Chapter 15 (Energy) requirements and Energy Community Treaty obligations.

From an economic development perspective, the significance cannot be overstated. The existing Italy-Montenegro HVDC submarine cable (the MONITA project, a 445 km interconnector with 600 MW capacity expandable to 1,200 MW) provides the physical infrastructure for market coupling. With this legal framework in place, Montenegro is on track for day-ahead market coupling with Italy by Q1 2028, which would make it the first Western Balkan country to achieve direct market coupling with an EU member state. This positions Montenegro as a potential energy trading hub for the entire Trans-Balkan Corridor connecting Serbia, Romania, and the wider region with Western European markets.

The investment signaling effect is substantial. The EBRD's record 215 million EUR investment in Montenegro in 2025, with 47% directed toward the green transition, demonstrates that international financial institutions are already responding to Montenegro's energy reform trajectory. The first international renewable energy auctions launched in July 2025 with EBRD support, covering 250 MW of solar capacity, and the expansion of the Gvozd wind farm to 75 MW, indicate growing investor confidence. The completed transposition reinforces this momentum by providing the legal certainty that energy investors require.

However, the Ministry identifies significant risks related to price convergence. Montenegro's industrial electricity prices currently sit in the range of 130 to 170 EUR per MWh, which is already moderately high by regional standards. Full market coupling with Italy and the broader EU could create upward pressure on domestic electricity prices, as EU wholesale prices tend to be higher. This is particularly concerning given Montenegro's industrial history: the KAP aluminium smelter in Podgorica, which once consumed up to 40% of national electricity and was a major employer, was forced to shut down in 2021-2023 precisely because electricity prices rose beyond economically viable levels for energy-intensive production. Any remaining or future energy-intensive industry would face similar pressures under full market integration.

The CBAM (Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism) dimension adds another layer of complexity. Approximately 57% of electricity imported by the EU from Western Balkan countries is coal-based, and Montenegro's coal-fired generation at Pljevlja has a carbon intensity of 1.0-1.1 tonnes CO2 per MWh, well above the EU average. While Montenegro has introduced a national cap-and-trade scheme, its carbon price of approximately 24 EUR per tonne is significantly below the EU ETS price. Without alignment, Montenegro's electricity exports to the EU via the interconnector will face substantial CBAM costs, potentially reducing export revenues that could otherwise benefit the national economy.

For SMEs and entrepreneurs, the impact is mixed. A more integrated and competitive electricity market should in theory lead to more efficient price formation and improved supply security. However, SMEs in Montenegro already face relatively high energy costs compared to regional competitors in Serbia or Bulgaria. The transition period must include measures to ensure that SMEs are not disproportionately burdened by price adjustments.

The labor market implications are modestly positive in the medium term. Energy market integration could attract investment in renewable energy projects, grid modernization, and energy services, creating skilled employment opportunities. The EBRD's 35 million EUR loan for electricity distribution system digitalization is one example. However, these jobs require technical skills that Montenegro's labor market may not readily supply without targeted workforce development.

The decision is also notable for what it does not address: Montenegro has no gas market and no gas network, meaning the natural gas provisions of the Cross-border Exchange Law are largely aspirational. While this is not a criticism of the transposition itself, the Ministry notes that economic diversification of energy sources remains incomplete.

On balance, this is an exemplary case of regulatory reform advancing economic integration. The achievement of completing transposition ahead of most Energy Community contracting parties demonstrates institutional capacity and political commitment. The critical challenge now shifts to implementation, verification by the Energy Community Secretariat and European Commission, and ensuring that the domestic economy is prepared to operate within an integrated European electricity market.
key_concerns: Price convergence with EU electricity markets could increase costs for domestic industrial consumers, SMEs, and households, particularly given Montenegro's already moderately high industrial electricity prices of 130-170 EUR per MWh

Montenegro's coal-based electricity generation at Pljevlja faces significant CBAM exposure, with carbon intensity of 1.0-1.1 tonnes CO2 per MWh and a domestic carbon price far below the EU ETS level, potentially eroding export revenues

The verification process by the Energy Community Secretariat and European Commission introduces timeline uncertainty, and any delays could stall investor confidence and market coupling plans targeted for Q1 2028

Montenegro lacks energy-intensive industrial capacity to benefit from potential electricity export revenues, following the KAP aluminium smelter shutdown, meaning market coupling benefits may flow primarily through trading margins rather than domestic industrial value creation
Workforce readiness for new energy sector jobs in grid modernization, renewables, and energy trading is uncertain given existing skills gaps in Montenegro's labor market
The natural gas component of the Cross-border Exchange Law is largely symbolic, as Montenegro has no gas infrastructure, leaving the country reliant on a single energy vector for market integration
recommendations: Establish an Industrial Energy Competitiveness Task Force to model the impact of EU market coupling on domestic electricity prices across all consumer categories and develop mitigation measures before SDAC/SIDC access goes live

Accelerate renewable energy deployment beyond the current 250 MW solar auction pipeline to diversify the generation mix, reduce CBAM exposure, and create downward pressure on long-term electricity costs for the domestic economy

Align the national carbon price closer to EU ETS levels on a phased timeline, ensuring that carbon revenues are recycled domestically into just transition measures and renewable investment rather than lost to CBAM payments to the EU

Develop a targeted SME energy transition support program, building on the existing EBRD-EU SME Go Green programme, to help small businesses invest in energy efficiency and on-site generation before market price adjustments take effect

Create an energy sector workforce development program in partnership with universities and vocational institutions, focusing on grid operations, renewable energy technology, and electricity market trading skills

Proactively engage the Energy Community Secretariat and European Commission to initiate the verification process immediately and set concrete milestones to maintain momentum toward the Q1 2028 market coupling target with Italy

Commission a strategic study on attracting new energy-intensive industries or data centers to Montenegro that could leverage both the interconnector capacity and expanding renewable generation, replacing the economic role once played by KAP

counter_proposal.title: Integrated Market Readiness and Industrial Competitiveness Package
counter_proposal.summary: While the Ministry strongly supports the completed transposition, it would complement this legislative achievement with a parallel economic readiness package. Rather than treating energy market integration as a standalone regulatory exercise, the Ministry would bundle it with concrete industrial competitiveness measures, ensuring that the benefits of market coupling flow through to the real economy. This includes a price impact mitigation framework, an accelerated renewable pipeline, carbon price alignment with domestic revenue recycling, and a strategic industrial attraction program targeting energy-intensive sectors that can leverage Montenegro's unique interconnector position.
key_changes: Adopt a Price Impact Mitigation Framework establishing transitional support mechanisms for industrial consumers and SMEs during the first three years of market coupling, funded by interconnector congestion revenues

Launch a Fast-Track Renewable Acceleration Program targeting 500 MW of additional renewable capacity by 2029, doubling the current pipeline, with priority given to projects that can deliver competitively priced power purchase agreements for domestic industry

Implement a phased carbon price escalation roadmap aligned with EU ETS convergence by 2030, with all revenues ring-fenced for domestic energy transition investment and just transition support in Pljevlja and other affected communities

Establish a Montenegro Energy Hub Strategy to attract data centers, green hydrogen production, or other energy-intensive investments that can exploit the strategic position between EU and Western Balkan electricity markets
Create a dedicated Energy Market Skills Academy in partnership with EBRD and EU funds to train 500 professionals in energy trading, grid management, and renewable technology within three years
expected_benefits: Domestic industry and SMEs protected from sudden price shocks during market integration transition period
Montenegro positioned as a regional energy hub generating trading revenues and attracting high-value investment
CBAM costs mitigated through domestic carbon pricing, with revenues retained nationally for green transition rather than flowing to the EU budget
New employment created in renewable energy, grid modernization, energy trading, and energy-intensive industries attracted by competitive renewable power
Faster and more credible progress on EU accession Chapters 15 (Energy) and 20 (Enterprise and Industrial Policy)
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High feasibility. The legislative foundation is already in place through the completed transposition. The price mitigation framework can be implemented through government regulation using existing EPCG and CGES institutional structures. Renewable acceleration builds on proven EBRD cooperation and the July 2025 auction model. Carbon price alignment has political precedent through the existing national cap-and-trade scheme. The main constraint is fiscal space for transition support, but this can be partially addressed through interconnector congestion revenues and EU pre-accession IPA III funds.
