The Energy Hub Strategy requires more complex investor engagement but aligns with EBRD's demonstrated willingness to invest at record levels in Montenegro.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Integrisani paket spremnosti tržišta i industrijske konkurentnosti
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Iako Ministarstvo snažno podržava završenu transpoziciju, ono bi ovaj zakonodavni uspjeh dopunilo paralelnim paketom ekonomske spremnosti. Umjesto da integraciju tržišta energije tretira kao izolovanu regulatornu vježbu, Ministarstvo bi je objedinilo s konkretnim mjerama industrijske konkurentnosti, osiguravajući da koristi od tržišnog spajanja dostignu realnu ekonomiju. To uključuje okvir za ublažavanje uticaja na cijene, ubrzani obnovljivi kanal, usklađivanje cijene ugljenika s domaćim recikliranjem prihoda, te strateški program privlačenja industrije usmjeren na energetski intenzivne sektore koji mogu iskoristiti jedinstvenu poziciju Crne Gore u interkonektoru.
key_changes_mne: Usvojiti Okvir za ublažavanje uticaja na cijene kojim se uspostavljaju prelazni mehanizmi podrške za industrijske potrošače i MSP tokom prve tri godine tržišnog spajanja, finansiran prihodima od zagušenja interkonektora

Pokrenuti Program ubrzanog razvoja obnovljivih izvora energije s ciljem postizanja dodatnih 500 MW obnovljivih kapaciteta do 2029. godine, čime se udvostručuje trenutni plan, s prioritetom projektima koji mogu ponuditi konkurentno cijenjene ugovore o kupovini električne energije za domaću industriju

Implementirati fazni plan eskalacije cijene ugljenika usklađen s konvergencijom EU ETS do 2030. godine, pri čemu su svi prihodi namjenski rezervisani za domaća ulaganja u energetsku tranziciju i podršku pravednoj tranziciji u Pljevljima i ostalim pogođenim zajednicama

Uspostaviti Strategiju Crne Gore kao energetskog čvorišta radi privlačenja data centara, proizvodnje zelenog vodonika ili drugih energetski intenzivnih ulaganja koja mogu iskoristiti strateški položaj između tržišta električne energije EU i Zapadnog Balkana

Osnovati namjensku Akademiju za vještine u oblasti tržišta energije u partnerstvu s EBRD-om i fondovima EU, s ciljem obuke 500 stručnjaka iz oblasti energetskog trgovanja, upravljanja mrežom i tehnologije obnovljivih izvora u roku od tri godine
expected_benefits_mne: Domaća industrija i MSP zaštićeni od naglih cjenovnih šokova tokom prelaznog perioda integracije tržišta
Crna Gora pozicionirana kao regionalno energetsko čvorište koje generiše prihode od trgovanja i privlači visoko vrijedna ulaganja
Troškovi CBAM ublaženi domaćim određivanjem cijene ugljenika, pri čemu prihodi ostaju u zemlji za zelenu tranziciju umjesto da odlaze u budžet EU
Otvorena nova radna mjesta u sektoru obnovljive energije, modernizacije mreže, energetskog trgovanja i energetski intenzivnih industrija privučenih konkurentnom obnovljivom energijom
Brži i kredibilniji napredak u poglavljima EU pristupnih pregovora 15 (Energetika) i 20 (Preduzetništvo i industrijska politika)
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka izvodljivost. Zakonodavni temelj je već uspostavljen završenom transpozicijom. Okvir za ublažavanje uticaja na cijene može se implementirati putem vladine uredbe koristeći postojeće institucionalne strukture EPCG i CGES. Ubrzanje obnovljivih izvora nadovezuje se na dokazanu saradnju s EBRD-om i model aukcija iz jula 2025. godine. Usklađivanje cijene ugljenika ima politički presedan kroz postojeću nacionalnu šemu ograničavanja i trgovanja emisijama. Glavno ograničenje je fiskalni prostor za tranzicijsku podršku, ali to se može djelimično riješiti prihodima od zagušenja interkonektora i fondovima EU pretpristupne pomoći IPA III. Strategija energetskog čvorišta zahtijeva složeniji angažman investitora, ali je u skladu s dokazanom spremnošću EBRD-a da ulaže na rekordnom nivou u Crnu Goru.

assessments.summary_mne: Završetak transpozicije paketa integracije tržišta električne energije predstavlja prekretničko dostignuće za ekonomski razvoj i konkurentnost Crne Gore. Postajući treća ugovorna strana Energetske zajednice koja je dovršila ovaj proces, Crna Gora se pozicionirala da pristupi Jedinstvenoj tržišnici za dan unaprijed (SDAC) i Jedinstvenoj intradnevnoj tržišnici (SIDC) EU prije formalnog pristupanja Uniji, prvenstveno putem postojećeg podmorskog HVDC kabla kapaciteta 600 MW između Italije i Crne Gore. Ova odluka šalje jasne investicione signale, jača energetsku bezbjednost, usklađuje se sa zahtjevima pristupanja EU i može podstaći ulaganja u obnovljive izvore energije. Međutim, Ministarstvo napominje da kuplovanje tržišta s cijenama EU nosi rizike od pritiska na rast cijena za domaće industrijske potrošače i domaćinstva, a koristi će se ostvariti samo ako implementacija i verifikacija budu sprovedene bez odlaganja.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ovo je jedno od najznačajnijih dostignuća ekonomske politike na putu Crne Gore ka EU integracijama, koje otvara pristup integrisanom tržištu električne energije EU putem interkonekcije između Italije i Crne Gore i šalje snažne signale investitorima u energetski sektor. Ključna briga odnosi se na to da bi konvergencija cijena s višim tržištima električne energije EU mogla povećati troškove za domaću industriju i mala i srednja preduzeća, ukoliko se to ne ublaži povećanjem kapaciteta iz obnovljivih izvora i ciljanom podrškom. Ministarstvo preporučuje hitan paralelni tok mjera za energetsku konkurentnost industrije i ubrzano uvođenje obnovljivih izvora energije, kako bi tržišna integracija donijela korist realnoj ekonomiji.
key_concerns_mne: Konvergencija cijena s tržištima električne energije EU mogla bi povećati troškove za domaće industrijske potrošače, mala i srednja preduzeća i domaćinstva, naročito imajući u vidu već umjereno visoke industrijske cijene električne energije u Crnoj Gori, koje iznose 130–170 EUR po MWh

Proizvodnja električne energije iz uglja u termoelektrani Pljevlja izložena je značajnom riziku od CBAM mehanizma, s intenzitetom ugljika od 1,0–1,1 tona CO2 po MWh i domaćom cijenom ugljika daleko ispod nivoa EU ETS, što bi moglo umanjiti prihode od izvoza

Proces verifikacije od strane Sekretarijata Energetske zajednice i Evropske komisije unosi neizvjesnost u pogledu rokova, a eventualna kašnjenja mogla bi narušiti povjerenje investitora i planove kuplovanja tržišta predviđene za prvi kvartal 2028. godine

Crna Gora ne raspolaže energetski intenzivnim industrijskim kapacitetima koji bi mogli iskoristiti potencijalne prihode od izvoza električne energije, nakon zatvaranja aluminijumskog kombinata KAP, što znači da bi koristi od kuplovanja tržišta mogle primarno ići kroz trgovinske marže, a ne kroz domaće industrijsko stvaranje vrijednosti

Kadrovska osposobljenost za nova radna mjesta u energetskom sektoru u oblasti modernizacije mreže, obnovljivih izvora energije i trgovine energijom neizvjesna je, uzimajući u obzir postojeće nedostatke u vještinama na crnogorskom tržištu rada

Komponenta prirodnog gasa u Zakonu o prekograničnoj razmjeni uglavnom je simboličnog karaktera, s obzirom na to da Crna Gora nema gasnu infrastrukturu, što zemlju ostavlja zavisnom od jednog energetskog vektora u procesu tržišne integracije
recommendations_mne: Osnovati Radnu grupu za energetsku konkurentnost industrije radi modeliranja uticaja kuplovanja s tržištem EU na domaće cijene električne energije u svim kategorijama potrošača i izrade mjera ublažavanja prije nego što pristupi SDAC/SIDC postanu operativni

Ubrzati razvoj obnovljivih izvora energije izvan trenutnog pipeline-a solarnih aukcija od 250 MW, u cilju diverzifikacije miksa proizvodnje, smanjenja izloženosti CBAM mehanizmu i stvaranja pritiska pada dugoročnih troškova električne energije za domaću privredu

Uskladiti nacionalnu cijenu ugljika s nivoima EU ETS prema faznom planu, osiguravajući da se prihodi od ugljika recikliraju u domaće mjere pravedne tranzicije i ulaganja u obnovljive izvore energije, umjesto da odlaze u EU putem CBAM plaćanja

Razviti ciljani program podrške malim i srednjim preduzećima u energetskoj tranziciji, nadovezujući se na postojeći EBRD-EU program SME Go Green, kako bi se malim preduzećima pomoglo da ulažu u energetsku efikasnost i lokalnu proizvodnju energije prije nego što tržišna usklađivanja cijena stupe na snagu

Kreirati program razvoja radne snage u energetskom sektoru u partnerstvu s univerzitetima i strukovnim institucijama, s fokusom na upravljanje mrežom, tehnologije obnovljivih izvora energije i vještine trgovanja na tržištu električne energije

Proaktivno angažovati Sekretarijat Energetske zajednice i Evropsku komisiju radi pokretanja procesa verifikacije bez odlaganja i utvrđivanja konkretnih prekretnica za održavanje zamaha ka cilju kuplovanja tržišta s Italijom u prvom kvartalu 2028. godine

Naručiti stratešku studiju o privlačenju novih energetski intenzivnih industrija ili data centara u Crnu Goru koji bi mogli iskoristiti i kapacitet interkonekcije i rastuću obnovljivu proizvodnju, nadomještajući ekonomsku ulogu koju je nekada imao KAP

assessments.summary: The completion of the EU electricity market integration package transposition is a fiscally significant and strategically sound achievement. It positions Montenegro to access the Single Day-Ahead Market (SDAC) and Single Intraday Market (SIDC) via its 600 MW submarine interconnector with Italy, potentially generating substantial new revenue streams from more efficient cross-border electricity trade. This directly supports EU accession -- now accelerating with 13 of 33 chapters provisionally closed -- and strengthens Montenegro's negotiating position on the energy acquis. However, the fiscal implications are double-edged: market coupling will inevitably push domestic electricity prices toward European levels, creating pressure to phase out EPCG's below-market pricing (currently over 60% below market rates), which will require costly social protection measures and risk political backlash. The Ministry of Finance must prepare for both the revenue upside and the fiscal exposure from transitional subsidies, CBAM-related costs on coal-fired generation, and necessary grid modernization investments.
assessments.executive_summary: This decision earns a strongly positive verdict because EU electricity market integration unlocks significant revenue potential from cross-border trade via the Italy interconnector and directly advances Montenegro's EU accession timeline. The top concern is the inevitable fiscal pressure from electricity price convergence toward EU levels, which will require new social protection spending estimated at tens of millions of euros annually. The Ministry recommends establishing a dedicated Energy Transition Fiscal Reserve funded by a portion of increased electricity trade revenues to cushion the transition.
assessments.reasoning:
From a fiscal policy perspective, this transposition represents one of the most consequential regulatory achievements for Montenegro's medium-term economic outlook. The ability to participate in SDAC and SIDC through the 600 MW Monita interconnector with Italy (with plans to double capacity to 1,200 MW by 2031) transforms Montenegro from a bilateral electricity trader into a participant in Europe's most liquid power market. This should improve price discovery, increase export revenues during periods of surplus hydro generation, and reduce import costs during deficit periods.

The revenue implications are material. Montenegro's electricity generation mix -- approximately 53% hydropower and 38% lignite -- means that in wet hydrological years, substantial surplus generation can be exported at EU market prices rather than bilateral contract prices. Under current arrangements, Montenegro exported significant volumes to Italy in 2023, but without market coupling, these transactions do not capture optimal pricing. SDAC participation could increase per-MWh export revenues by a meaningful margin, though exact figures depend on market conditions.

However, the fiscal risks are equally significant. First, market coupling will create irresistible pressure to align domestic electricity prices with European levels. Currently, EPCG maintains prices more than 60% below EU market rates, effectively providing an implicit subsidy to all consumers. As market integration proceeds, maintaining this price gap becomes fiscally unsustainable and legally problematic under EU state aid rules. The OECD has documented that Montenegro provided EUR 88 million in energy sector financial support between 2018-2023, with EUR 21.1 million in direct fiscal transfers. These figures will likely need to increase substantially during the price convergence period to protect vulnerable consumers.

Second, the CBAM dimension adds fiscal complexity. Montenegro faces estimated annual CBAM exposure of up to EUR 190 million, though Montenegro's position is more favorable than regional peers because hydropower structurally limits its carbon intensity. Notably, Montenegro is the only Western Balkan economy with an operational carbon pricing system (national ETS since 2020), which provides partial CBAM credit. However, the coal-fired Pljevlja thermal power plant remains a significant carbon liability. Market coupling will make this liability more transparent and financially material.

Third, implementation costs should not be underestimated. Full compliance with the electricity integration package requires investments in market operator systems, transmission system operator capabilities, cybersecurity infrastructure, and regulatory capacity. REGAGEN and COTEE (the market and system operators) will need upgraded IT platforms compatible with EU market coupling algorithms (EUPHEMIA for day-ahead, XBID for intraday). These costs, while modest relative to potential benefits, require budget allocation.

On the positive side for public finances, this decision directly supports Montenegro's EU accession trajectory. With Chapter 32 (financial control) recently closed and accelerating momentum toward the goal of closing all chapters in 2026, demonstrating concrete progress on the energy acquis strengthens Montenegro's credibility. The Reform Agenda 2024-2027 specifically targets electricity market integration, and this milestone shows compliance with agreed benchmarks. This matters fiscally because EU accession unlocks access to substantially larger EU funds (structural, cohesion, agricultural) that dwarf current IPA allocations.

The decision also sends positive investment signals. The combination of legal certainty from the new Energy Law, Cross-border Electricity and Natural Gas Exchange Law, and implementing decrees creates a framework that international investors, particularly in renewables, can rely on. The recently launched Renewable Energy Sources Association (with EBRD and EU support) benefits directly from this regulatory clarity. Foreign direct investment in energy infrastructure generates tax revenues, creates employment, and reduces Montenegro's current account deficit.

Regarding public debt implications (currently near 60% of GDP with financing needs of approximately 14% of GDP in 2025-2026), the decision is modestly positive. While it does not directly reduce debt, improved electricity trade revenues flowing through state-owned EPCG could improve the fiscal position over time, and enhanced EU accession prospects improve Montenegro's sovereign credit profile and borrowing costs.

The timing is also notable in the context of Montenegro's euroization. Using the euro without ECB membership means Montenegro cannot use monetary policy to manage energy price shocks. Fiscal policy is the only available macroeconomic stabilization tool. Market integration, while beneficial long-term, increases exposure to EU electricity price volatility, making fiscal buffers more important than ever.
key_concerns: Domestic electricity prices will face upward convergence pressure toward EU market levels, currently more than 60% above Montenegrin retail prices, requiring significant new social protection spending

EPCG's below-cost pricing model becomes unsustainable under market coupling, creating fiscal exposure if the government must subsidize the transition explicitly rather than through implicit EPCG cross-subsidies
Implementation costs for market operator IT systems, cybersecurity, and regulatory capacity upgrades require near-term budget allocation with no immediate revenue return

CBAM exposure from Pljevlja coal plant operations will become more financially transparent and costly under integrated market conditions, with estimated national CBAM costs of up to EUR 190 million annually
Montenegro's euroization means no monetary policy tools are available to manage energy price volatility shocks that market coupling may transmit, placing full burden on fiscal policy
Financing needs already at 14% of GDP in 2025-2026 leave limited fiscal headroom for energy transition investments and consumer protection measures
recommendations: Establish an Energy Transition Fiscal Reserve within the 2027 budget framework, funded by earmarking a percentage of incremental EPCG revenues from SDAC/SIDC participation, to finance vulnerable consumer protection during price convergence

Develop a phased electricity price alignment roadmap with REGAGEN that gradually closes the gap to EU market prices over 3-5 years, with clearly defined annual adjustment caps and automatic social transfer triggers
Accelerate carbon pricing alignment by increasing the national ETS price trajectory toward EU ETS levels to maximize CBAM credits and reduce the net fiscal impact of carbon border adjustments

Commission an independent fiscal impact assessment of full SDAC/SIDC participation, quantifying expected revenue gains, implementation costs, and consumer subsidy requirements before the European Commission verification process concludes

Negotiate with EU institutions for transitional arrangements or technical assistance funding to cover market coupling implementation costs, leveraging Montenegro's frontrunner status among Energy Community contracting parties
Include energy market integration milestones as explicit conditions in EPCG's performance framework, linking state-owned enterprise dividend policy to successful market coupling implementation

counter_proposal.title: Fiscally Anchored Market Integration Strategy
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Finance would complement the current legislative transposition with a comprehensive fiscal management framework that pairs market integration with explicit budgetary planning. Rather than treating the fiscal consequences of market coupling as an afterthought, this approach would front-load fiscal preparation by establishing ring-fenced revenue mechanisms, binding price convergence schedules, and pre-committed social protection instruments before verification and market coupling proceed.
key_changes: Create a statutory Energy Market Integration Fund within the budget, capitalized initially at EUR 15-20 million from existing EPCG dividends, with automatic top-up mechanisms linked to cross-border trade revenues

Mandate REGAGEN to publish an annual Fiscal Impact Report on electricity market integration, including projected subsidy costs, CBAM exposure, and revenue forecasts, to be submitted to Parliament alongside the annual budget

Condition the government's formal verification request to the Energy Community Secretariat on completion of a consumer impact assessment and activation of enhanced social transfer mechanisms for energy-vulnerable households

Require EPCG to publish a market coupling business plan with five-year financial projections, including expected changes to retail pricing, wholesale revenue, and capital expenditure requirements for grid compatibility
Integrate CBAM mitigation planning into the market coupling timeline by accelerating the Pljevlja thermal plant transition plan and linking coal phase-out milestones to market integration milestones
expected_benefits: Prevents fiscal surprise by quantifying and pre-funding the costs of electricity price convergence before they materialize
Protects vulnerable consumers through automatic stabilization mechanisms rather than ad hoc political interventions
Improves sovereign creditworthiness by demonstrating proactive fiscal management of energy transition risks to rating agencies and IMF surveillance
Maximizes CBAM credit capture by synchronizing carbon pricing reforms with market integration timeline
Strengthens EU accession credibility by showing that Montenegro can manage complex economic transitions with fiscal discipline
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High feasibility. The proposed measures are administrative and legislative in nature, requiring no additional external financing. The Energy Market Integration Fund can be capitalized from existing EPCG dividend flows (EPCG paid significant dividends in recent years). The fiscal impact reporting requirement aligns with Chapter 32 (financial control) obligations already accepted. The main political challenge is making electricity price convergence explicit and scheduled rather than leaving it ambiguous, but this is preferable to unplanned fiscal shocks.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Strategija Integrisanja Tržišta Zasnovana na Fiskalnom Sidru
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Ministarstvo finansija bi dopunilo trenutnu zakonodavnu transpoziciju sveobuhvatnim okvirom fiskalnog upravljanja koji spaja integraciju tržišta s eksplicitnim budžetskim planiranjem. Umjesto da se fiskalne posljedice spajanja tržišta tretiraju kao naknadna misao, ovaj pristup bi unaprijed pripremio fiskalne mjere uspostavljanjem mehanizama prihoda sa zaštićenim namjenama, obavezujućih rasporeda konvergencije cijena i unaprijed posvećenih instrumenata socijalne zaštite – prije nego što verifikacija i spajanje tržišta budu sprovedeni.
key_changes_mne: Osnivanje zakonskog Fonda za integraciju energetskog tržišta u okviru budžeta, s početnim kapitalom od 15–20 miliona EUR iz postojećih dividendi EPCG-a, uz automatske mehanizme dopune vezane za prihode od prekograničnoj trgovine

Obavezati REGAGEN da objavljuje godišnji Izvještaj o fiskalnom uticaju integracije elektroenergetskog tržišta, koji uključuje projektovane troškove subvencija, izloženost CBAM-u i prognoze prihoda, a koji se podnosi Skupštini zajedno s godišnjim budžetom

Usloviti zvaničan zahtjev Vlade za verifikaciju upućen Sekretarijatu Energetske zajednice završetkom procjene uticaja na potrošače i aktivacijom unaprijeđenih mehanizama socijalnih transfera za domaćinstva ugrožena visokim cijenama energije

Obavezati EPCG da objavi poslovni plan spajanja tržišta s petogodišnjim finansijskim projekcijama, uključujući očekivane promjene u maloprodajnim cijenama, prihodima od veleprodaje i kapitalnim rashodima potrebnim za kompatibilnost mreže

Integrisati planiranje mjera za ublažavanje uticaja CBAM-a u vremenski okvir spajanja tržišta ubrzavanjem plana tranzicije termoelektrane Pljevlja i vezivanjem ključnih tačaka postupnog ukidanja uglja za ključne tačke integracije tržišta
expected_benefits_mne: Sprečava fiskalna iznenađenja kvantifikacijom i unaprijed obezbjeđivanjem sredstava za troškove konvergencije cijena električne energije, prije nego što se oni materijalizuju
Štiti ugrožene potrošače putem automatskih mehanizama stabilizacije, a ne ad hoc političkih intervencija
Poboljšava suverenitet kreditne sposobnosti demonstriranjem proaktivnog fiskalnog upravljanja rizicima energetske tranzicije pred rejting agencijama i u okviru nadzora MMF-a
Maksimizira iskorišćavanje kreditnih olakšica u okviru CBAM-a sinhronizacijom reformi cijena ugljika s vremenskim okvirom integracije tržišta
Jača kredibilitet u procesu pristupanja EU pokazujući da Crna Gora može upravljati složenim ekonomskim tranzicijama uz fiskalnu disciplinu
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka izvodljivost. Predložene mjere su administrativne i zakonodavne prirode i ne zahtijevaju dodatno vanjsko finansiranje. Fond za integraciju energetskog tržišta može biti kapitalizovan iz postojećih tokova dividendi EPCG-a (EPCG je u posljednjih nekoliko godina isplaćivao značajne dividende). Zahtjev za fiskalnim izvještavanjem o uticaju usklađen je s obavezama iz Poglavlja 32 (finansijska kontrola) koje su već prihvaćene. Glavni politički izazov jeste eksplicitno utvrđivanje i vremensko planiranje konvergencije cijena električne energije, umjesto ostavljanja iste u nedorečenom stanju – međutim, to je poželjnije od neplaniranih fiskalnih šokova.

assessments.summary_mne: Završetak transpozicije paketa integracije tržišta električne energije EU predstavlja fiskalno značajno i strateški opravdano dostignuće. Ono pozicionira Crnu Goru da pristupi Jedinstvenom tržištu za dan unaprijed (SDAC) i Jedinstvenom intradnevnom tržištu (SIDC) putem podmorskog interkonekcijskog kabla kapaciteta 600 MW s Italijom, što bi moglo generisati značajne nove tokove prihoda zahvaljujući efikasnijem prekograničnom trgovanju električnom energijom. To direktno podržava pristupanje EU – koje sada ubrzava s 13 od 33 poglavlja privremeno zatvorena – i jača pregovaračku poziciju Crne Gore u pogledu energetskog acquisa. Međutim, fiskalne implikacije su dvosjekle: tržišno spajanje će neizbježno gurnuti domaće cijene električne energije prema evropskim nivoima, stvarajući pritisak za ukidanje ispodtržišnih cijena EPCG-a (trenutno više od 60% ispod tržišnih cijena), što će zahtijevati skupe mjere socijalne zaštite i nosi rizik od političkih otpora. Ministarstvo finansija mora se pripremiti kako za potencijalni rast prihoda, tako i za fiskalnu izloženost koja proizilazi iz tranzicionih subvencija, troškova vezanih za CBAM na proizvodnju iz uglja, te neophodnih investicija u modernizaciju mreže.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ova odluka zaslužuje izrazito pozitivnu ocjenu, budući da integracija tržišta električne energije EU otvara značajan prihodni potencijal od prekogranične trgovine putem interkonekcijskog kabla s Italijom i direktno ubrzava pristupanje Crne Gore EU. Glavni razlog za zabrinutost predstavlja neizbježan fiskalni pritisak uslijed usklađivanja cijena električne energije prema nivoima EU, koji će zahtijevati nova izdvajanja za socijalnu zaštitu procijenjena na desetine miliona eura godišnje. Ministarstvo preporučuje uspostavljanje namjenskih Fiskalnih rezervi za energetsku tranziciju, finansiranih dijelom povećanih prihoda od trgovine električnom energijom, kako bi se ublažile posljedice tranzicije.
key_concerns_mne: Domaće cijene električne energije suočiće se s pritiskom usklađivanja prema nivoima tržišta EU, koje su trenutno više od 60% iznad maloprodajnih cijena u Crnoj Gori, što će zahtijevati značajno povećanje rashoda za socijalnu zaštitu

Model ispodtržišnih cijena EPCG-a postaje neodrživ u uslovima tržišnog spajanja, što stvara fiskalnu izloženost ukoliko vlada bude morala eksplicitno subvencionisati tranziciju, umjesto da se oslanja na implicitne unakrsne subvencije EPCG-a
Troškovi implementacije IT sistema tržišnog operatera, sajber bezbjednosti i unapređenja regulatornih kapaciteta zahtijevaju kratkoročnu budžetsku alokaciju bez neposrednog povrata prihoda

Izloženost CBAM-u zbog rada termoelektrane na ugalj u Pljevljima postaće finansijski transparentnija i skuplja u uslovima integrisanog tržišta, s procijenjenim nacionalnim troškovima CBAM-a do 190 miliona EUR godišnje

Euroizacija Crne Gore znači da nema monetarnih instrumenata za upravljanje šokovima volatilnosti cijena energije koje tržišno spajanje može prenositi, čime se cjelokupan teret prebacuje na fiskalnu politiku
Potrebe za finansiranjem koje već iznose 14% BDP-a u periodu 2025–2026. ostavljaju ograničen fiskalni prostor za investicije u energetsku tranziciju i mjere zaštite potrošača
recommendations_mne: Uspostaviti Fiskalne rezerve za energetsku tranziciju u okviru budžetskog okvira za 2027. godinu, finansirane namjenskim usmjeravanjem dijela inkrementalnih prihoda EPCG-a od učešća na SDAC/SIDC tržištima, radi finansiranja zaštite ugroženih potrošača tokom perioda usklađivanja cijena

Razviti fazni plan usklađivanja cijena električne energije zajedno s REGAGEN-om, koji postepeno zatvara jaz do tržišnih cijena EU tokom perioda od 3 do 5 godina, s jasno definisanim godišnjim ograničenjima prilagođavanja i automatskim okidačima za socijalne transfere
Ubrzati usklađivanje cijena ugljika povećanjem nacionalne putanje ETS cijena prema nivoima EU ETS-a, kako bi se maksimizovali CBAM krediti i smanjio neto fiskalni uticaj graničnih korekcija ugljika

Naručiti nezavisnu fiskalnu procjenu uticaja punog učešća na SDAC/SIDC tržištima, s kvantifikacijom očekivanih prihoda, troškova implementacije i potrebnih potrošačkih subvencija, prije okončanja procesa verifikacije Evropske komisije

Pregovarati s institucijama EU o tranzicionim aranžmanima ili fondovima tehničke pomoći za pokrivanje troškova implementacije tržišnog spajanja, iskorišćavanjem pionirskog statusa Crne Gore među ugovornim stranama Energetske zajednice

Uključiti ključne etape integracije tržišta električne energije kao eksplicitne uslove u okvir performansi EPCG-a, povezujući politiku dividendi državnog preduzeća s uspješnom implementacijom tržišnog spajanja

debate.consensus_summary: All nine ministries assessed the decision as positive or better, yielding a rare near-unanimous cross-government endorsement. There is broad agreement that completing the transposition of the EU Electricity Integration Package is a significant EU accession milestone that strengthens Montenegro's negotiating position on Chapter 15 (Energy), positions the country as a regional frontrunner among Western Balkans candidate states, and opens a concrete pathway to join the EU Single Day-Ahead Market and Single Intraday Market via the 600 MW Italy-Montenegro submarine cable before formal EU membership. All ministries further agree that legislative transposition alone is insufficient and that operational implementation, institutional capacity-building, and timely verification by the Energy Community Secretariat and European Commission are essential next steps. There is also universal recognition that electricity price convergence toward EU market levels is inevitable and will require social mitigation measures, though ministries differ on the urgency and scope of such measures.
disagreements: Social protection timing and adequacy: The Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare (neutral, 5/10) and the Ministry of Health argue that vulnerable consumer protection frameworks and social impact assessments should have been adopted alongside or before the February 15 decrees, while the Ministry of Economy and Ministry of EU Integration treat social mitigation as a downstream implementation matter that should not delay the market integration timeline.

Coal phase-out timeline: The Ministry of Environment insists that Montenegro should adopt a binding coal exit date no later than 2035 and condition SDAC/SIDC participation on this commitment, while the Ministry of Economy focuses on managing the transition without specifying an accelerated deadline, and the current government position retains the 2041 phase-out date for TPP Pljevlja, which the Environment ministry considers inconsistent with EU climate neutrality targets.

Executive decree-making versus parliamentary oversight: The Ministry of Justice raises concerns that the two government decrees adopted on February 15 bypassed full parliamentary legislative scrutiny, and recommends ex-post committee review. Other ministries do not address this procedural dimension, treating the decrees as routine delegated legislation.

Cybersecurity and critical infrastructure readiness: The Ministry of Interior emphasizes that Montenegro's energy infrastructure remains inadequately protected against cyber threats, citing the devastating August 2022 cyberattack, and argues that a comprehensive security impact assessment should precede the formal verification request. The Ministry of EU Integration and Ministry of Economy prioritize speed, recommending immediate submission of the verification request within 30 days.

Electricity price convergence pace: The Ministry of Finance advocates a phased 3-5 year price alignment roadmap with annual adjustment caps, while the Ministry of Economy and EU Integration emphasize that market coupling inherently requires price convergence and focus on capturing revenue benefits rather than delaying price adjustments. The Ministry of Tourism warns that price convergence could erode Montenegro's cost competitiveness against regional rivals.

Workforce readiness: The Ministry of Education flags the absence of any workforce development component in the transposition package and warns that the late-2026/early-2027 market coupling timeline leaves insufficient time for training, while other ministries acknowledge skills gaps but do not treat them as blocking issues.

Environmental conditionality: The Ministry of Environment recommends earmarking a percentage of cross-border trade revenues for renewable energy and just transition, and mandating Strategic Environmental Assessments for new infrastructure. The Ministry of Economy and Ministry of Finance do not include environmental earmarks in their recommendations, focusing instead on fiscal reserves and industrial competitiveness.
debate.debate_transcript:
PARLIAMENTARY DEBATE TRANSCRIPT -- Skupstina Crne Gore, Committee for Economy, Finance and Budget, joint session with Committee for European Integration. Subject: Montenegro's Completion of the EU Electricity Market Integration Package Transposition. Date: 21 February 2026.

--- OPENING CONTEXT ---

The debate takes place against the backdrop of Montenegro's accelerating EU accession process, with 13 of 33 negotiation chapters provisionally closed as of January 2026 and the government targeting closure of all remaining chapters within the year. The Energy Community Secretariat announced on 20-21 February that Montenegro has completed transposition of the Electricity Integration Package, becoming the third contracting party after Serbia and Moldova. The government adopted the final two decrees on system operations and emergency situations on 15 February 2026. Public attention to the decision has been moderate, with coverage by CdM, RTNK, Adria TV, MINA, and regional energy outlets including Balkan Green Energy News, Montel News, and SeeNews. Civil society response has been limited, though Bankwatch has previously flagged Montenegro's weak emissions trading cap and coal dependency, and the PRIF Blog published analysis on 13 February warning that CBAM and market coupling risk deepening energy poverty across the Western Balkans.

--- RULING COALITION POSITION: EUROPE NOW / URA ---

The ruling Europe Now/URA coalition presents this transposition as one of the government's signature EU accession achievements. The coalition argues that completing the legislative package demonstrates Montenegro's institutional capacity and reform commitment, positioning the country ahead of most Western Balkans peers. The coalition emphasizes three strategic benefits: first, that SDAC/SIDC access via the 600 MW Italy-Montenegro submarine cable will generate new revenue streams from more efficient cross-border electricity trade and improve energy supply security; second, that the achievement directly advances Chapter 15 closing benchmarks and strengthens Montenegro's hand at the next Intergovernmental Conference; and third, that market coupling is essential for avoiding hundreds of millions of euros in annual CBAM costs, which have been fully operational since January 2026 and are estimated at EUR 190-350 million annually on coal-fired electricity exports.

The Europe Now bloc, consistent with its economically liberal and digitalisation-focused platform, frames the decision as a modernisation milestone. It cites the Ministry of Economy's and Ministry of Finance's strongly positive assessments (both 9/10 and 8/10 respectively) and the Ministry of EU Integration's assessment (9/10) as validation. The coalition argues that Montenegro must now move swiftly to submit the formal verification request within 30 days and maintain the Q1 2028 timeline for Italy-Montenegro day-ahead market coupling. It points to the January 2026 Masdar-EPCG joint venture announcement for renewable energy development as evidence that the investment signals from market integration are already materialising.

URA, the green-liberal junior coalition partner, adds that market coupling will expose TPP Pljevlja's true cost of carbon-intensive generation to competitive price signals, creating economic incentives for accelerated renewable energy deployment. URA emphasises the 346 MW solar potential identified on brownfield sites and the 2,300 MW offshore wind potential identified in recent studies, arguing that the legislative framework now in place makes these investments bankable. However, URA diverges from its senior coalition partner by insisting that environmental conditionality must accompany implementation, echoing the Ministry of Environment's recommendation for binding coal exit dates and earmarked revenues for green transition.

--- OPPOSITION POSITION: DPS / SDP ---

The DPS-led opposition acknowledges the legislative achievement but frames its response around three critiques: implementation credibility, social protection gaps, and democratic process concerns.

On implementation credibility, the opposition notes that the 2025 Energy Community Implementation Report flagged only limited progress on Montenegro's broader Chapter 15 action plan, suggesting that the government's legislative ambition outpaces institutional capacity. The opposition argues this is consistent with a pattern observed across multiple negotiation chapters where formal transposition is celebrated while substantive implementation lags, a concern echoed in the China-CEE Institute's February 2026 briefing which observed that 'procedural success will not translate into the resolution of Montenegro's internal problems.' The opposition cites the Ministry of EU Integration's own acknowledgement that Montenegro risks legislative achievement being cited as sufficient progress while implementation gaps persist.

On social protection, the DPS-led bloc amplifies the Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare's neutral assessment (5/10), the lowest score among all ministries. The opposition argues that adopting the two decrees without any accompanying vulnerable consumer protection framework or social impact assessment was irresponsible. It highlights OECD data showing that EPCG's below-market pricing has provided approximately EUR 1.16 billion in induced support to consumers between 2018-2023, with household prices currently more than 60 percent below EU market levels. The opposition warns that price convergence without targeted social transfers will deepen energy poverty among the 14-30 percent of households already struggling with energy costs and the quarter of the population that reported inability to maintain adequate home heating in 2023. The SDP in particular emphasises workers' rights concerns, noting that over 1,000 workers will be directly affected by the Pljevlja transition and that the decrees appear to have been adopted without meaningful social dialogue with energy sector trade unions or the Social Council.

On democratic process, the opposition echoes the Ministry of Justice's concern that the two February 15 decrees were adopted by executive action without full parliamentary scrutiny. The opposition argues that energy market integration affects every Montenegrin household and business, and that measures of this consequence deserve transparent legislative debate, not delegated executive decree-making. The opposition calls for ex-post parliamentary committee review and insists that all secondary legislation implementing the package must come before the relevant committees.

--- NATIONALIST BLOC POSITION: DF / DNP ---

The DF/DNP bloc frames the electricity market integration through the lens of sovereignty and national economic control. This bloc argues that coupling Montenegro's electricity market with EU mechanisms before actual EU membership amounts to surrendering control over a strategic national resource without obtaining the full benefits of membership. The bloc questions why Montenegro is rushing to expose its consumers and industries to EU market prices when the country has not yet secured the structural funds, cohesion support, or transitional exemptions that actual EU member states receive.

The nationalist bloc raises concerns about energy sovereignty, arguing that dependence on the Italy-Montenegro submarine cable for market access creates strategic vulnerability. It notes that Montenegro's electricity generation is concentrated in two state entities, EPCG's hydropower and the Pljevlja thermal plant, and that market coupling could undermine the state's ability to manage electricity as a public good. The bloc points to the Ministry of Interior's cybersecurity warnings, arguing that the 2022 cyberattack demonstrated that Montenegro cannot adequately protect critical infrastructure and that deeper digital integration with EU market systems will expand the attack surface.

The DNP, which the China-CEE February 2026 briefing identifies as a strategically crucial player capable of conditioning parliamentary majorities, uses this debate to advocate for slower integration timelines and explicit sovereignty safeguards. The bloc argues that the government should not submit the verification request until comprehensive security assessments, social protection frameworks, and just transition funding are in place. However, this position carries limited weight in the committee given the bloc's smaller seat share and the broad cross-party consensus favouring EU integration.

--- MINORITY PARTIES POSITION: BS / FORCA / ALBANIAN ALTERNATIVE ---

The minority party representatives focus on two dimensions: equitable distribution of market integration benefits, and the impact on economically vulnerable minority communities.

These parties note that energy poverty disproportionately affects minority communities in northern and eastern municipalities, where infrastructure investment has historically lagged behind the coastal and central regions. They argue that the price convergence risks identified by the Ministry of Labour and the Ministry of Health will fall hardest on communities already experiencing higher unemployment, lower incomes, and weaker public services. They call for the vulnerable consumer protection framework to include explicit disaggregated monitoring by municipality and demographic group to ensure that market integration does not widen existing regional disparities.

The minority bloc supports EU integration as a framework for rights protection and institutional modernisation, and therefore endorses the transposition as a positive step. However, it insists that implementation must include meaningful consultation with local self-governments in affected regions and that IPA III pre-accession assistance should be directed toward energy infrastructure in underserved municipalities.

--- CROSS-CUTTING THEMES FROM MINISTRY ASSESSMENTS ---

Cybersecurity and Critical Infrastructure (Ministry of Interior, score 7/10): The committee heard strong caution from the interior affairs perspective. The August 2022 cyberattack that forced power plants onto manual control demonstrates unresolved vulnerabilities. The Ministry argues that the Cybersecurity Strategy 2022-2026 is expiring without a successor that accounts for real-time cross-border energy market risks, and recommends a dedicated energy-sector cybersecurity unit within the national CIRT structure before verification proceeds.

Workforce Readiness (Ministry of Education, score 7/10): The education perspective emphasises a critical gap: no workforce development or skills training component accompanies this regulatory transposition. The Ministry warns that VET curricula do not yet cover energy trading, market coupling operations, or EU regulatory compliance, and that the Faculty of Electrical Engineering's curricula may not be aligned with cross-border market integration requirements. With EPCG expecting market coupling by late 2026 or early 2027, the training pipeline is severely compressed.

Healthcare Infrastructure (Ministry of Health, score 7/10): The health ministry flags that Montenegro's 18 public healthcare facilities are major energy consumers operating in aging buildings, and that the June 2024 regional blackout exposed critical vulnerabilities in hospital backup power systems. It calls for all public healthcare facilities to be designated as protected consumers and for the EBRD-funded EUR 12 million hospital energy efficiency renovation programme to be accelerated before market coupling takes effect.

Fiscal Implications (Ministry of Finance, score 8/10): The finance perspective is strongly positive but highlights the double-edged fiscal reality. Market coupling offers revenue upside through more efficient cross-border trade, but EPCG's below-cost pricing model becomes unsustainable, creating fiscal exposure if the government must subsidise the transition explicitly. Montenegro's euroisation means no monetary policy tools are available to manage energy price volatility, placing the full burden on fiscal policy. Financing needs already at 14 percent of GDP in 2025-2026 leave limited fiscal headroom.

Tourism Competitiveness (Ministry of Tourism, score 7/10): The tourism ministry raises a sector-specific alarm: electricity price convergence could substantially increase operating costs for hotels and tourism accommodation during the peak May-October season, eroding Montenegro's price advantage against Croatia, Albania, and Greece. No tourism-specific energy cost mitigation measures have been announced.

Judicial Oversight (Ministry of Justice, score 7/10): The justice perspective focuses on constitutional compliance and anti-corruption safeguards. It flags concerns about the emergency situations decree requiring proportionality and judicial review safeguards, EPCG's dominant market position creating corruption risks with expanded cross-border financial flows, and the need for whistleblower protection provisions consistent with the EU Whistleblower Directive.

--- COMMITTEE DELIBERATION SUMMARY ---

The committee finds that the completion of the EU Electricity Market Integration Package transposition commands broad support across the parliamentary spectrum, with disagreements centring on pace, sequencing, and social safeguards rather than the fundamental direction of reform. The weighted ministerial average score of approximately 7.3 out of 10 reflects genuine enthusiasm tempered by legitimate concerns.

The strongest consensus exists around the EU accession value of the decision. Even the DPS opposition, which has historically championed Montenegro's European path, cannot and does not oppose the substance of the transposition, limiting its critique to implementation quality and social protection gaps. The nationalist bloc's sovereignty objections, while aired, do not attract significant cross-party support in a parliament where pro-EU parties hold a commanding majority.

The most substantive tension is between speed and safeguards. The ruling coalition and the ministries of Economy, Finance, and EU Integration prioritise rapid verification and maintaining the Q1 2028 market coupling timeline, arguing that each month of delay extends CBAM cost exposure. The opposition, supported by the ministries of Labour, Interior, and Education, argues that rushing to market coupling without social protection frameworks, cybersecurity readiness, and workforce preparation will create downstream crises that undermine public support for the broader EU integration project.

The committee notes that civil society engagement with this decision has been surprisingly limited, despite its far-reaching implications for household energy costs. Bankwatch's prior warnings about Montenegro's weak emissions trading cap and the PRIF Blog's February 2026 analysis on energy affordability pressures in the Western Balkans suggest that public awareness of price convergence risks has not yet crystallised into organised advocacy. The committee recommends proactive government communication about the transition timeline and social protection measures to prevent a backlash when prices begin to adjust.

The overall parliamentary assessment is positive. The decision is sound in its strategic direction and EU integration value, but it requires urgent complementary action on social protection, cybersecurity, workforce development, environmental safeguards, and parliamentary oversight to ensure that the benefits of market integration are broadly shared and the risks are managed. The committee calls on the government to present a comprehensive implementation roadmap, including timelines for vulnerable consumer protection, a successor cybersecurity strategy, workforce training programmes, and a phased price alignment plan, before the formal verification request is submitted.
debate.consensus_summary_mne: All nine ministries assessed the decision as positive or better, yielding a rare near-unanimous cross-government endorsement. There is broad agreement that completing the transposition of the EU Electricity Integration Package is a significant EU accession milestone that strengthens Montenegro's negotiating position on Chapter 15 (Energy), positions the country as a regional frontrunner among Western Balkans candidate states, and opens a concrete pathway to join the EU Single Day-Ahead Market and Single Intraday Market via the 600 MW Italy-Montenegro submarine cable before formal EU membership. All ministries further agree that legislative transposition alone is insufficient and that operational implementation, institutional capacity-building, and timely verification by the Energy Community Secretariat and European Commission are essential next steps. There is also universal recognition that electricity price convergence toward EU market levels is inevitable and will require social mitigation measures, though ministries differ on the urgency and scope of such measures.
disagreements_mne: Social protection timing and adequacy: The Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare (neutral, 5/10) and the Ministry of Health argue that vulnerable consumer protection frameworks and social impact assessments should have been adopted alongside or before the February 15 decrees, while the Ministry of Economy and Ministry of EU Integration treat social mitigation as a downstream implementation matter that should not delay the market integration timeline.

Coal phase-out timeline: The Ministry of Environment insists that Montenegro should adopt a binding coal exit date no later than 2035 and condition SDAC/SIDC participation on this commitment, while the Ministry of Economy focuses on managing the transition without specifying an accelerated deadline, and the current government position retains the 2041 phase-out date for TPP Pljevlja, which the Environment ministry considers inconsistent with EU climate neutrality targets.

Executive decree-making versus parliamentary oversight: The Ministry of Justice raises concerns that the two government decrees adopted on February 15 bypassed full parliamentary legislative scrutiny, and recommends ex-post committee review. Other ministries do not address this procedural dimension, treating the decrees as routine delegated legislation.

Cybersecurity and critical infrastructure readiness: The Ministry of Interior emphasizes that Montenegro's energy infrastructure remains inadequately protected against cyber threats, citing the devastating August 2022 cyberattack, and argues that a comprehensive security impact assessment should precede the formal verification request. The Ministry of EU Integration and Ministry of Economy prioritize speed, recommending immediate submission of the verification request within 30 days.

Electricity price convergence pace: The Ministry of Finance advocates a phased 3-5 year price alignment roadmap with annual adjustment caps, while the Ministry of Economy and EU Integration emphasize that market coupling inherently requires price convergence and focus on capturing revenue benefits rather than delaying price adjustments. The Ministry of Tourism warns that price convergence could erode Montenegro's cost competitiveness against regional rivals.

Workforce readiness: The Ministry of Education flags the absence of any workforce development component in the transposition package and warns that the late-2026/early-2027 market coupling timeline leaves insufficient time for training, while other ministries acknowledge skills gaps but do not treat them as blocking issues.

Environmental conditionality: The Ministry of Environment recommends earmarking a percentage of cross-border trade revenues for renewable energy and just transition, and mandating Strategic Environmental Assessments for new infrastructure. The Ministry of Economy and Ministry of Finance do not include environmental earmarks in their recommendations, focusing instead on fiscal reserves and industrial competitiveness.

PARLIAMENTARY DEBATE TRANSCRIPT -- Skupstina Crne Gore, Committee for Economy, Finance and Budget, joint session with Committee for European Integration. Subject: Montenegro's Completion of the EU Electricity Market Integration Package Transposition. Date: 21 February 2026.

--- OPENING CONTEXT ---

The debate takes place against the backdrop of Montenegro's accelerating EU accession process, with 13 of 33 negotiation chapters provisionally closed as of January 2026 and the government targeting closure of all remaining chapters within the year. The Energy Community Secretariat announced on 20-21 February that Montenegro has completed transposition of the Electricity Integration Package, becoming the third contracting party after Serbia and Moldova. The government adopted the final two decrees on system operations and emergency situations on 15 February 2026. Public attention to the decision has been moderate, with coverage by CdM, RTNK, Adria TV, MINA, and regional energy outlets including Balkan Green Energy News, Montel News, and SeeNews. Civil society response has been limited, though Bankwatch has previously flagged Montenegro's weak emissions trading cap and coal dependency, and the PRIF Blog published analysis on 13 February warning that CBAM and market coupling risk deepening energy poverty across the Western Balkans.

--- RULING COALITION POSITION: EUROPE NOW / URA ---

The ruling Europe Now/URA coalition presents this transposition as one of the government's signature EU accession achievements. The coalition argues that completing the legislative package demonstrates Montenegro's institutional capacity and reform commitment, positioning the country ahead of most Western Balkans peers. The coalition emphasizes three strategic benefits: first, that SDAC/SIDC access via the 600 MW Italy-Montenegro submarine cable will generate new revenue streams from more efficient cross-border electricity trade and improve energy supply security; second, that the achievement directly advances Chapter 15 closing benchmarks and strengthens Montenegro's hand at the next Intergovernmental Conference; and third, that market coupling is essential for avoiding hundreds of millions of euros in annual CBAM costs, which have been fully operational since January 2026 and are estimated at EUR 190-350 million annually on coal-fired electricity exports.

The Europe Now bloc, consistent with its economically liberal and digitalisation-focused platform, frames the decision as a modernisation milestone. It cites the Ministry of Economy's and Ministry of Finance's strongly positive assessments (both 9/10 and 8/10 respectively) and the Ministry of EU Integration's assessment (9/10) as validation. The coalition argues that Montenegro must now move swiftly to submit the formal verification request within 30 days and maintain the Q1 2028 timeline for Italy-Montenegro day-ahead market coupling. It points to the January 2026 Masdar-EPCG joint venture announcement for renewable energy development as evidence that the investment signals from market integration are already materialising.

URA, the green-liberal junior coalition partner, adds that market coupling will expose TPP Pljevlja's true cost of carbon-intensive generation to competitive price signals, creating economic incentives for accelerated renewable energy deployment. URA emphasises the 346 MW solar potential identified on brownfield sites and the 2,300 MW offshore wind potential identified in recent studies, arguing that the legislative framework now in place makes these investments bankable. However, URA diverges from its senior coalition partner by insisting that environmental conditionality must accompany implementation, echoing the Ministry of Environment's recommendation for binding coal exit dates and earmarked revenues for green transition.

--- OPPOSITION POSITION: DPS / SDP ---

The DPS-led opposition acknowledges the legislative achievement but frames its response around three critiques: implementation credibility, social protection gaps, and democratic process concerns.

On implementation credibility, the opposition notes that the 2025 Energy Community Implementation Report flagged only limited progress on Montenegro's broader Chapter 15 action plan, suggesting that the government's legislative ambition outpaces institutional capacity. The opposition argues this is consistent with a pattern observed across multiple negotiation chapters where formal transposition is celebrated while substantive implementation lags, a concern echoed in the China-CEE Institute's February 2026 briefing which observed that 'procedural success will not translate into the resolution of Montenegro's internal problems.' The opposition cites the Ministry of EU Integration's own acknowledgement that Montenegro risks legislative achievement being cited as sufficient progress while implementation gaps persist.

On social protection, the DPS-led bloc amplifies the Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare's neutral assessment (5/10), the lowest score among all ministries. The opposition argues that adopting the two decrees without any accompanying vulnerable consumer protection framework or social impact assessment was irresponsible. It highlights OECD data showing that EPCG's below-market pricing has provided approximately EUR 1.16 billion in induced support to consumers between 2018-2023, with household prices currently more than 60 percent below EU market levels. The opposition warns that price convergence without targeted social transfers will deepen energy poverty among the 14-30 percent of households already struggling with energy costs and the quarter of the population that reported inability to maintain adequate home heating in 2023. The SDP in particular emphasises workers' rights concerns, noting that over 1,000 workers will be directly affected by the Pljevlja transition and that the decrees appear to have been adopted without meaningful social dialogue with energy sector trade unions or the Social Council.

On democratic process, the opposition echoes the Ministry of Justice's concern that the two February 15 decrees were adopted by executive action without full parliamentary scrutiny. The opposition argues that energy market integration affects every Montenegrin household and business, and that measures of this consequence deserve transparent legislative debate, not delegated executive decree-making. The opposition calls for ex-post parliamentary committee review and insists that all secondary legislation implementing the package must come before the relevant committees.

--- NATIONALIST BLOC POSITION: DF / DNP ---

The DF/DNP bloc frames the electricity market integration through the lens of sovereignty and national economic control. This bloc argues that coupling Montenegro's electricity market with EU mechanisms before actual EU membership amounts to surrendering control over a strategic national resource without obtaining the full benefits of membership. The bloc questions why Montenegro is rushing to expose its consumers and industries to EU market prices when the country has not yet secured the structural funds, cohesion support, or transitional exemptions that actual EU member states receive.

The nationalist bloc raises concerns about energy sovereignty, arguing that dependence on the Italy-Montenegro submarine cable for market access creates strategic vulnerability. It notes that Montenegro's electricity generation is concentrated in two state entities, EPCG's hydropower and the Pljevlja thermal plant, and that market coupling could undermine the state's ability to manage electricity as a public good. The bloc points to the Ministry of Interior's cybersecurity warnings, arguing that the 2022 cyberattack demonstrated that Montenegro cannot adequately protect critical infrastructure and that deeper digital integration with EU market systems will expand the attack surface.

The DNP, which the China-CEE February 2026 briefing identifies as a strategically crucial player capable of conditioning parliamentary majorities, uses this debate to advocate for slower integration timelines and explicit sovereignty safeguards. The bloc argues that the government should not submit the verification request until comprehensive security assessments, social protection frameworks, and just transition funding are in place. However, this position carries limited weight in the committee given the bloc's smaller seat share and the broad cross-party consensus favouring EU integration.

--- MINORITY PARTIES POSITION: BS / FORCA / ALBANIAN ALTERNATIVE ---

The minority party representatives focus on two dimensions: equitable distribution of market integration benefits, and the impact on economically vulnerable minority communities.

These parties note that energy poverty disproportionately affects minority communities in northern and eastern municipalities, where infrastructure investment has historically lagged behind the coastal and central regions. They argue that the price convergence risks identified by the Ministry of Labour and the Ministry of Health will fall hardest on communities already experiencing higher unemployment, lower incomes, and weaker public services. They call for the vulnerable consumer protection framework to include explicit disaggregated monitoring by municipality and demographic group to ensure that market integration does not widen existing regional disparities.

The minority bloc supports EU integration as a framework for rights protection and institutional modernisation, and therefore endorses the transposition as a positive step. However, it insists that implementation must include meaningful consultation with local self-governments in affected regions and that IPA III pre-accession assistance should be directed toward energy infrastructure in underserved municipalities.

--- CROSS-CUTTING THEMES FROM MINISTRY ASSESSMENTS ---

Cybersecurity and Critical Infrastructure (Ministry of Interior, score 7/10): The committee heard strong caution from the interior affairs perspective. The August 2022 cyberattack that forced power plants onto manual control demonstrates unresolved vulnerabilities. The Ministry argues that the Cybersecurity Strategy 2022-2026 is expiring without a successor that accounts for real-time cross-border energy market risks, and recommends a dedicated energy-sector cybersecurity unit within the national CIRT structure before verification proceeds.

Workforce Readiness (Ministry of Education, score 7/10): The education perspective emphasises a critical gap: no workforce development or skills training component accompanies this regulatory transposition. The Ministry warns that VET curricula do not yet cover energy trading, market coupling operations, or EU regulatory compliance, and that the Faculty of Electrical Engineering's curricula may not be aligned with cross-border market integration requirements. With EPCG expecting market coupling by late 2026 or early 2027, the training pipeline is severely compressed.

Healthcare Infrastructure (Ministry of Health, score 7/10): The health ministry flags that Montenegro's 18 public healthcare facilities are major energy consumers operating in aging buildings, and that the June 2024 regional blackout exposed critical vulnerabilities in hospital backup power systems. It calls for all public healthcare facilities to be designated as protected consumers and for the EBRD-funded EUR 12 million hospital energy efficiency renovation programme to be accelerated before market coupling takes effect.

Fiscal Implications (Ministry of Finance, score 8/10): The finance perspective is strongly positive but highlights the double-edged fiscal reality. Market coupling offers revenue upside through more efficient cross-border trade, but EPCG's below-cost pricing model becomes unsustainable, creating fiscal exposure if the government must subsidise the transition explicitly. Montenegro's euroisation means no monetary policy tools are available to manage energy price volatility, placing the full burden on fiscal policy. Financing needs already at 14 percent of GDP in 2025-2026 leave limited fiscal headroom.

Tourism Competitiveness (Ministry of Tourism, score 7/10): The tourism ministry raises a sector-specific alarm: electricity price convergence could substantially increase operating costs for hotels and tourism accommodation during the peak May-October season, eroding Montenegro's price advantage against Croatia, Albania, and Greece. No tourism-specific energy cost mitigation measures have been announced.

Judicial Oversight (Ministry of Justice, score 7/10): The justice perspective focuses on constitutional compliance and anti-corruption safeguards. It flags concerns about the emergency situations decree requiring proportionality and judicial review safeguards, EPCG's dominant market position creating corruption risks with expanded cross-border financial flows, and the need for whistleblower protection provisions consistent with the EU Whistleblower Directive.

--- COMMITTEE DELIBERATION SUMMARY ---

The committee finds that the completion of the EU Electricity Market Integration Package transposition commands broad support across the parliamentary spectrum, with disagreements centring on pace, sequencing, and social safeguards rather than the fundamental direction of reform. The weighted ministerial average score of approximately 7.3 out of 10 reflects genuine enthusiasm tempered by legitimate concerns.

The strongest consensus exists around the EU accession value of the decision. Even the DPS opposition, which has historically championed Montenegro's European path, cannot and does not oppose the substance of the transposition, limiting its critique to implementation quality and social protection gaps. The nationalist bloc's sovereignty objections, while aired, do not attract significant cross-party support in a parliament where pro-EU parties hold a commanding majority.

The most substantive tension is between speed and safeguards. The ruling coalition and the ministries of Economy, Finance, and EU Integration prioritise rapid verification and maintaining the Q1 2028 market coupling timeline, arguing that each month of delay extends CBAM cost exposure. The opposition, supported by the ministries of Labour, Interior, and Education, argues that rushing to market coupling without social protection frameworks, cybersecurity readiness, and workforce preparation will create downstream crises that undermine public support for the broader EU integration project.

The committee notes that civil society engagement with this decision has been surprisingly limited, despite its far-reaching implications for household energy costs. Bankwatch's prior warnings about Montenegro's weak emissions trading cap and the PRIF Blog's February 2026 analysis on energy affordability pressures in the Western Balkans suggest that public awareness of price convergence risks has not yet crystallised into organised advocacy. The committee recommends proactive government communication about the transition timeline and social protection measures to prevent a backlash when prices begin to adjust.

The overall parliamentary assessment is positive. The decision is sound in its strategic direction and EU integration value, but it requires urgent complementary action on social protection, cybersecurity, workforce development, environmental safeguards, and parliamentary oversight to ensure that the benefits of market integration are broadly shared and the risks are managed. The committee calls on the government to present a comprehensive implementation roadmap, including timelines for vulnerable consumer protection, a successor cybersecurity strategy, workforce training programmes, and a phased price alignment plan, before the formal verification request is submitted.

blind_spots: No ministry addressed the fact that Serbia entered the verification phase in October 2025 and is months ahead operationally. Montenegro completing transposition third is a legislative milestone, not a competitive advantage -- the real race is verification and implementation, where Montenegro has not yet even submitted its formal request.

The coal mine concession in Pljevlja runs until 2050, nine years beyond the stated 2041 coal phase-out date for the power plant. No ministry flagged this fundamental contradiction, which undermines the credibility of Montenegro's decarbonization commitments and signals that coal extraction may continue for non-power purposes or that the phase-out date is aspirational.

EPCG's governance crisis is the elephant in the room. The state utility reported declining profitability in 2024, with subsidiaries like EPCG-Solar Gradnja and EPCG-Zeljeznara Niksic performing poorly. Board appointments remain politically influenced. No ministry assessed whether EPCG as an institution is actually ready to operate as a competitive market participant in SDAC/SIDC, rather than as a state-directed monopoly.

The Ministry of EU Integration cited EUR 190-350 million in annual CBAM costs for Montenegro specifically, but the Bankwatch report from which this figure appears to derive provides only regional aggregates (EUR 965 million for all Western Balkans). The Montenegro-specific figure appears inflated or unsourced, and no ministry challenged it.

No ministry discussed the practical readiness of the Montenegrin Power Exchange (MEPX), launched only in 2023, to handle SDAC/SIDC operations. MEPX's liquidity, technical systems, and staffing levels are critical to whether transposition translates into actual market participation.

The natural gas provisions of the Cross-border Electricity and Natural Gas Exchange Law are entirely symbolic since Montenegro has zero gas infrastructure. Only the Ministry of Economy acknowledged this in passing. Transposing gas market rules that cannot be applied is a form of hollow compliance that the Energy Community Secretariat may flag during verification.

No ministry assessed the risk that market coupling could make Montenegro a transit corridor for cheap Balkan coal power flowing to Italy, perversely increasing regional emissions rather than reducing them, unless robust Guarantees of Origin and carbon accounting are enforced.

REGAGEN's actual regulatory independence was not scrutinized by any ministry. The EU's own progress reports have noted concerns about regulatory independence in Montenegro's energy sector, yet no assessment questioned whether REGAGEN has the capacity and political independence to make market-consistent regulatory decisions once coupling is live.
critic_report.overall_analysis: This decision is a genuine and welcome policy achievement. Completing transposition of the EU Electricity Integration Package is the necessary legal foundation for Montenegro to eventually join European electricity markets, and doing so as only the third Energy Community contracting party demonstrates institutional capability. The ministries broadly got the substance right, and several (Interior, Labour, Environment) deserve credit for raising uncomfortable secondary consequences rather than simply applauding. That said, there is a pattern of overstatement running through the assessments. The decision is being framed as near-transformational when it is, in reality, completing the paperwork. The hard part starts now. Serbia entered its verification phase in October 2025 and could achieve market coupling before Montenegro despite completing transposition earlier. Montenegro has not yet submitted its formal verification request. The verification process itself has no guaranteed timeline, and the technical activities phase lasts approximately 18 months, meaning even an optimistic scenario puts actual market coupling at late 2028 or 2029 rather than the frequently cited Q1 2028. During this gap period, CBAM is already operational (since January 1, 2026), meaning every megawatt-hour of coal-fired electricity exported to Italy via the submarine cable incurs carbon border costs. Montenegro does have a national emissions trading scheme since 2020, but Bankwatch has explicitly stated the carbon price is too low to qualify for CBAM exemption. This means Montenegro is currently losing revenue on every coal-based export. The CBAM figures cited by the Ministry of EU Integration (EUR 190-350 million annually) appear to lack a solid source for Montenegro specifically; the Bankwatch report provides only a regional aggregate of EUR 965 million for all Western Balkans electricity exports. The real Montenegro-specific exposure depends on export volumes and generation mix, which fluctuate significantly with hydrology. The energy poverty dimension raised by the Ministry of Labour is the most important citizen-facing concern and was underweighted in the overall scoring. OECD data confirms Montenegro's electricity prices are over 60% below market-consistent levels. Market coupling will create inexorable convergence pressure. Between 14 and 30 percent of households already experience energy poverty. The two February 15 decrees contain no social protection provisions whatsoever, and Montenegro's existing vulnerable consumer support is overwhelmingly non-means-tested, meaning price increases will hit low-income households hardest. The Ministry of Interior's cybersecurity concerns are well-founded and independently verifiable. The August 2022 cyberattack attributed to Russian-linked actors and the Cuba ransomware gang forced power plants to manual operation for approximately 20 days. The Cybersecurity Strategy 2022-2026 is expiring this year with no publicly announced successor. Real-time digital interconnection with EU market platforms through SDAC/SIDC integration dramatically increases the cyber attack surface, and Montenegro has demonstrably failed to defend against such attacks in the recent past. The most glaring structural issue none of the ministries adequately confronted is EPCG itself. The state utility's declining profitability, politically influenced governance, and role as both market participant and de facto social policy instrument (through below-cost pricing) creates fundamental conflicts of interest that market coupling will expose. EPCG cannot simultaneously be a competitive European market participant and a vehicle for providing 60%+ electricity price subsidies to the entire population. Something has to give, and no ministry was willing to say so clearly. On EU accession specifically, the decision genuinely helps Chapter 15 (Energy) progress, but the Energy Community's own 2025 Implementation Report noted only 'limited progress' on the broader Chapter 15 action plan despite good preparedness. The gap between legislative adoption and operational implementation is Montenegro's persistent weakness across all negotiation chapters, and experts from civil society organizations like the Centre for Civic Education have expressed skepticism that the institutional environment can deliver the acceleration needed. In sum: the transposition is real progress and the right policy direction. But the celebratory framing risks creating a false sense of accomplishment when the most difficult challenges -- verification, implementation, price reform, social protection, EPCG restructuring, and cybersecurity -- all lie ahead.

eu_chapter_relevance: Ch.15 Energy -- Direct and primary relevance. Completing transposition of the Electricity Integration Package satisfies key closing benchmarks for Chapter 15, which was opened in December 2015. However, the Energy Community's 2025 report flagged only limited implementation progress, meaning legislative transposition alone will not close this chapter.

Ch.23 Judiciary and Fundamental Rights -- The new legal framework expands regulatory decision-making by REGAGEN and the government through delegated decrees. Effective judicial review of these decisions, anti-corruption oversight of energy trading, and rule-of-law capacity to investigate market manipulation are all Chapter 23 concerns. Montenegro's prosecution of serious economic crime remains weak per EU assessments.

Ch.24 Justice, Freedom and Security -- Cybersecurity of critical energy infrastructure falls squarely under Chapter 24. The 2022 cyberattack demonstrated severe vulnerabilities. Cross-border energy trading also creates new channels for financial crime and money laundering that require Chapter 24-level law enforcement capacity.

Ch.27 Environment and Climate Change -- Market integration will affect the economics of coal-fired generation at Pljevlja and the pace of renewable energy deployment. The 2041 coal phase-out date is inconsistent with EU climate neutrality goals. Montenegro's weak national carbon pricing undermines both environmental objectives and CBAM positioning.

Ch.8 Competition Policy -- EPCG's dominant market position and state-controlled below-cost pricing constitute a significant state aid and competition concern. Market coupling requires competitive market structures, and EPCG's dual role as market participant and social policy instrument will need to be resolved under EU competition rules.

Ch.19 Social Policy and Employment -- Energy price convergence will hit vulnerable households hardest. The absence of social protection measures alongside transposition contradicts Chapter 19 expectations that economic reforms be accompanied by adequate social safeguards. The Pljevlja just transition affecting over 1,000 workers is a direct Chapter 19 concern.

Ch.16 Taxation -- Montenegro's national emissions trading scheme is too weak to qualify for CBAM exemption. Strengthening carbon pricing has direct fiscal and taxation implications, and alignment with EU ETS standards is a Chapter 16 and Chapter 15 cross-cutting issue.

Ch.33 Financial and Budgetary Provisions -- The fiscal exposure from CBAM costs, the need for transitional consumer subsidies during price convergence, and the investment requirements for grid modernization and market operator systems all have budgetary implications relevant to Chapter 33.

Ipak, u ocjenama se provlači obrazac preuveličavanja. Odluka se prikazuje kao gotovo transformativna, dok je u stvarnosti riječ o završavanju papirologije. Najteži dio tek predstoji.
